title: Allow override of `--tags` in profile
body:
Since merging #940 we are no longer able to override tags that we have specified in our profile.

e.g.

```js
module.exports = {
  default: '--tags "not @wip"'
}
```

We will routinely tag scenarios that we are currently working on with `@wip`.

```gherkin
Feature: A feature
  Scenario: A completed scenario
    Given it passes

  @wip
  Scenario: A scenario we're working on
    Given it currently fails
```

We expect these scenarios to fail and we don't want them to run as part of our build, but we do want to run them in development, e.g.:

```
$ cucumber -t @wip
```

This now results in the tag expression `not @wip and @wip`, and the scenarios don't run.

I realise this is at odds with the goal of #940 so I wanted to open the discussion.

@aslakhellesoy is this better tackled in tag expressions?

Perhaps: `not @wip and @wip` => `@wip` and `@wip and not @wip` => `not @wip`

title: cli: extract option splitting and use it for --compiler (#746)
body:
Thought I'd take a crack at #746 while I was dealing with `:` splitting for the formatters. The compiler isn't as easy to unit test as the formatters was since the result of the split is used internally to the config builder plus it actually `require`s the module so you can't just send anything you want to it...like a windows absolute path. So I added an `OptionSplitter` utility that both the `--format` and `--compiler` can use. There are no new tests for `--compiler` because of the reason above, but the existing [feature](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/master/features/compiler.feature) should ensure there are no regressions.

The splitting itself almost turned out to be simple with negative look aheads and look behinds until I found out that js regex doesn't support look behinds. That's why there's still a little bit of logic to smash those back together.

It's still splitting on a `:`, but not if it is preceded by a capital letter and followed by a `/` (at least that was my intention). I looked at [this old pr](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/680/files#diff-125eabbcc2e8302c4674fbbcc2fa3439R106), but couldn't tell if that would work in this situation. Regex hurts my head.

title: formatter and formatter output gets confused by windows absolute paths
body: The cli parses `-f C:/custom/formatter:C:/formatter/output` as `C` for the formatter and `/custom/formatter:C:/formatter/output` for the formatter output due to not taking in account that a `:` could appear in a windows path.

title: testCase does not contain Scenario name
body: When using 2.0.0, I used ScenarioResult to get the status of the test scenario and also the name of the current scenario. This was useful as I had a conditional statement on failure to take a screenshot and name it after the failed scenario, making it easy to see exactly where each scenario was falling. #919, I believe was used to 'fix' ScenarioResult as it was no longer functioning in more recent versions of Cucumber-js. I am now using V 3.0.3 as testCase gives me a similar function as ScenarioResult. However, unlike ScenarioResult, it does not contain the scenario name in the object (it does contain the status of the test though, at least). Is there a new method to get the name of the scenario? At the moment it seems to only give the name of the feature file this failure comes from, which is not specific enough for my needs. Thanks in advance :)

title: Support multiple --tags command-line arguments
body:
Could you please support  multiple `-t` arguments, presumably merging them into single `(...) and (...)` string before parsing it as a tag expression.

For example, if we define default profile as 

```
module.exports = {
  default: '-t "not @todo" --compiler js:babel-register'
}
```

and create a scenario in TDD fashion (i.e. Gherkin only, without passing implementation) marking it with an ignore tag

```
Feature: Foo

  @foo
  Scenario: Lorem
    When foo
    Then bar

  @foo @todo
  Scenario: Ipsum
    When baz
    Then qux
```

Now when you run the tests with some flag, e.g. `yarn test -t @foo`, it overrides the default ` not @todo` and executed unfinished scenario.

Would it be possible to support multiple tags, e.g. simple ``tags.map(tag =>`(${tag})`).join(' and ')`` to turn it into final tag expression before futher processing?

title: defineParameterType still requires typeName over name
JSON-file path and unique filenames
body:
After some searching I found the lines of code that write the JSON report, if provided in the `format` option, to a file, see [here](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/master/src/cli/index.js#L38).

I've got 2 issues / questions about it

1. `fs.open(path.resolve(this.cwd, outputTo), 'w')` is used to create the file. The `w` option _opens the file for writing. The file is created (if it does not exist) or truncated (if it exists)._ But this doesn't create the folder if it's not present and it will fail creating the file if the folder is not present. Is this a conscious choice or a bug? Or are you open for a PR that verifies if the folders already exists?
2. There are cases in which the file name is not unique because the file already exists from a different process / instance. This will overwrite the current report with the data of a new feature.  Is this a conscious choice or are you open for a PR where a unique filename is created when the file already exists?

I think this is related to https://github.com/protractor-cucumber-framework/protractor-cucumber-framework/issues/99

title: Before/After feature hooks and hacks
body:
I understand the reasoning behind not having BeforeFeature/AfterFeature feature hooks. Tests should ideally be isolated. However, for practical performance reasons it can be preferable to setup things like database fixtures once per feature.

The workaround specified in #614 is inadequate because:

1. It will not call After when consecutive features have the same tag.
2. It will not call After if the tagged feature was the last test in the build.

Previous to 3.0.0 it was possible to hack in this functionality using the context passed as the first argument of registerHandler('BeforeFeatures').

Any thoughts on accepting a PR for this functionality, or providing a similar context in 3.0 to at least make the hack possible again?

title: Can't define steps using "{string}" type notation
body:
I have the following step in my scenario:

`And I submit the add-salad command with caesar-salad, which costs 7`

Using Cucumber.js 2.31, I defined the following step definition and it worked fine:

`When("I submit the add-salad command with {string}, which costs {int}", function (saladName, amount) {`

However, after upgrading to Cucumber.js 3.0, this no longer works and I get the following error:

```
And I submit the add-salad command with caesar-salad, which costs 7
       Undefined. Implement with the following snippet:

         When('I submit the add-salad command with caesar-salad, which costs {int}', function (int, callback) {
           // Write code here that turns the phrase above into concrete actions
           callback(null, 'pending');
         });

```

According to the documentation at https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/master/docs/nodejs_example.md, I see no issue with my syntax and the fact that this worked fine before 3.0 leads me to believe that it is an issue in the latest version of Cucumber.

If I write the step definition as:

`When(/^I submit the add-salad command with (.*), which costs (\d*)$/, function (saladName, amount) {`

It works, however this is not an acceptable workaround for me as it interprets the type of the `amount` parameter as being a string, not a number.

title: Change duration to be in ticks

Other cucumber runner frameworks measure duration in nanoseconds. 

When duration was added to this project it was noted that it needed to be in nanoseconds. See comment by aslakhellesoy [here](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/125)

The reason I really want to make this change is that the duration ends up being represented as 0ms in reporting tools as the unit is too small

title: Allow cucumber to be used as an unreleased (git) dependency
body:
We sometimes want to use cucumber with features that haven't been released.

Adding `"cucumber": "cucumber/cucumber#some-branch"` to `package.json` will cause npm/yarn to pull from git, but it will *not* run babel over the files.

To make this work I've created a script that builds cucumber (if it's not already built), and trigger this in `postinstall`. I've also changed `prepublish` to use this script, to prevent babel from running twice.

This technique is already used in cucumber-expressions, and has been working nicely.

title: Allow absolute formatter output paths. Fixes #900.
body:
I needed this fix to get protractor support for cucumber 3.

  - Moved the invalid path scenario that was in `multiple_formattters.feature` to a new `formatter_paths.feature` so all the path related scenarios were together.
  - Added mustache to get the temp dir into the feature. ~~Added a new `replaceContextVariables` helper so that I could get the actual temp dir into the feature itself. It felt kind of hacky, but I didn't know of another way besides duplicating step definitions to deal with absolute paths explicitly.~~

title: Pass scenario argument to hooks. Fixes #891
body: Fixes a regression in `Before`/`After` so scenario result is passed. Added a regression test.

title: Deprecate typeName in favour of name when defining parameter types
body:
This deprecates `typeName` in favour of `name`, in order to be more aligned with [docs](https://docs.cucumber.io/cucumber-expressions/#custom-parameter-types) and other implementations.

It also exposes `useForSnippets` and `preferForRegexpMatch` which give finer grained control over snippet generation and regexp matching.

title: Scenario Outline name rename: pluralize word
body: This is tiny change on top of #899: pluralize a word in the Scenario Outline to make it fit the grammar of the sentence.

title: Would you be willing to consider a watch mode PR?
body:
Hey guys,

Would you be willing to consider a watch mode in cucumber? 
How I see it - 
rerunning .feature file when it changes ( easy )
rerunning a feature when its support code changes is more complex, but would be possible, we need to save the information about which .feature was connected to which .js files, when the .feature files first run. We start watching all js files that were used for the initial run, and then just look through that mapping structure whenever we change one of the js files. 

Do you have any insights into that? 

I would be willing to spent on it some hours, unless you think cucumber shouldn't have this feature, or unless you think it will be harder than I imagine :)

Thanks!

title: writing output to a file with an absolute path prevented in v3.0.0
body:
<!-- Please use the [support](https://cucumber.io/support) forums for questions 
and discussions which are not related to documentation updates, bug reports, or feature requests -->

<!-- Please search for related issues and check the documentation
before opening a new issue -->

<!-- If your issue is related to other tools (protractor, nightwatch, etc),
please open an issue on the related tool first and only open an issue here once
you have confirmed the issue is with cucumber -->

<!-- If you are reporting a bug, please include a minimal reproducible example
with the following environment information: cucumber version, node or browser version,
operating system -->

because of the [`path.join` with `this.cwd` passed to `fs.open` when preparing to write to a file](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/f11e30f437d2a4faea78ec5ffa351ad18c306f03/src/cli/index.js#L38), an absolute path is handled as relative to the project path instead of the root of the system when starting with a leading `/`. 

in my case this is breaking the ability for [circle-ci to process the cucumber report](https://circleci.com/docs/1.0/test-metadata/#cucumber) since `$CIRCLE_TEST_REPORTS=/tmp/circle-junit.aLqT5ZY` (or similar), but cucumber tries to write to `/home/ubuntu/<project-name>/tmp/circle-junit.aLqT5ZY/cucumber/tests.cucumber` instead of `/tmp/circle-junit.aLqT5ZY/cucumber/tests.cucumber`, as defined by the environment variable.

title: Replace process.exit() with process.exitCode
body:
Would it be possible to replace process.exit() calls (a couple in [run.js](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/master/src/cli/run.js) is all I could find) with process.exitCode as per Node.js recommendation linked below. It my case Cucumber.js terminates Node before async file logger has a chance to flush, among other possible pending operations in the event loop.

https://nodejs.org/api/process.html#process_process_exit_code

> It is important to note that calling process.exit() will force the process to exit as quickly as possible even if there are still asynchronous operations pending that have not yet completed fully, including I/O operations to process.stdout and process.stderr. In most situations, it is not actually necessary to call process.exit() explicitly. The Node.js process will exit on its own if there is no additional work pending in the event loop. The process.exitCode property can be set to tell the process which exit code to use when the process exits gracefully.

with the following environment information: cucumber version, node or browser version,
operating system -->

Following the docs, it appears you should be able to register a before all hook via `defineSupportCode`. However, on the latest release of cucumber (`2.3.1`), this is what is passed to the callback:


```js
{
  addTransform: [Function: deprecated],
  defineParameterType: [Function], 
  After: [Function], 
  Before: [Function], 
  defineStep: [Function], 
  registerHandler: [Function], 
  registerListener: [Function: registerListener], 
  setDefaultTimeout: [Function: setDefaultTimeout], 
  setDefinitionFunctionWrapper: [Function: setDefinitionFunctionWrapper], 
  setWorldConstructor: [Function: setWorldConstructor], 
  Then: [Function], 
  When: [Function], 
  Given: [Function] 
}
```

title: Add BeforeAll / AfterAll hooks
Allow unknown CLI options
body:
Commander by default throws an error when unexpected command-line option is present which is a problem when you try to pass additional arguments to the tests without specifying a 'command' but 'options' only, i.e. when using a profile.

For example the following works fine with `test/foo` and additional `--debug`:

    node node_modules/cucumber/bin/cucumber.js test/foo --require test/foo --debug

However the following throws an error `error: unknown option '--debug'` because `test/foo` directory is in profile definition:

    node node_modules/cucumber/bin/cucumber.js --profile foo --debug

The PR is to prevent Commander throwing exceptions when unexpected option is present and pass it verbatim to the tests.

title: Tags order affects which scenarios are filtered
body:
I could reproduce with cucumber 2.3.1 as well as 2.2.0. I couldn't see anything about order of tags in [the documentation](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/wiki/Tags), so I believe this is a bug.

Here is the minimum steps to reproduce:

1. Create the following feature file:
    ```gherkin
    @both
    Feature: Foo

      @a
      Scenario: a
        Given it is a test

      Scenario: b
        Given it is a test
    ```
2. Execute `./node_modules/.bin/cucumberjs --tags @both --tags @a`
    - This executes only scenario "a", which is expected.
3. Execute `./node_modules/.bin/cucumberjs --tags @a --tags @both`
    - This executes both scenario "a" and "b", although scenario "b" doesn't have the tag `@a`.

title: Ability to affect future testflow and structure
body:
Split from #873 :
> An alternate point of view: I don't know if it'll break a major design decision at the very core of cucumber, but it would be extremely useful if FeforeFeatures, BeforeFeature, BeforeScenario and BeforeStep could mutate their cucumber payloads and affect the behavior of the future testflow.
> 
> Among these mutations, a .skip() option would be a good first candidate to implement.
> 
> I imagine there're a lot of benefits to the testflow being immutable once it's loaded. Is it an intentional design feature in cucumber?

To clarify: 
Once cucumber begins to run (i.e. BeforeFeatures hook fires), the entire future test-flow has already been loaded and sequenced in memory. The features are ordered, and within each of them, the scenario order has been determined (all of them passed the run parameters tag filtering, of course).

It could be very helpful to manipulate this structure in ways that will affect the future test flow. These manipulations include:

**Skipping scenarios and features** - For example, say my selenium connection timed out on one of the ui tests, and I know from here on I'll just be waisting time trying to setup any other ui test. I would rather be able to skip any future scenario marked with `@ui` for this test run.

**Adding scenarios and features** - Some test environments are extremely asynchronous. i.e. some business processes may take several minutes (or more) to complete. A test that initiates an operation can add a validation scenario to the end of the test flow and allow all the other tests to run in between. Current solutions require the tests to be "forced" into the correct order by naming conventions, and the end-of-the-stack tests are ran even if the initiating scenarios failed.

**Reordering scenarios and features** - There can be reasons for running tests in different order in different situations. If it were possible to manipulate the features payload in BeforeFeatures, the infrastructure implementer could account for environment / launch parameters and manipulate the stack accordingly.

These are just some examples of the top of my head.

title: multiple asynchronous interfaces: update error message
body:
Currently if a function takes in a callback and returns promise, then this results in the error message: 
```
function uses multiple asynchronous interfaces: callback and promise
```
However, this can be a confusing error message if someone leaves an extra parameter in the step definition and thus is not intentionally using the callback interface. We should update the error message to be something more helpful like the following:
```
function uses multiple asynchronous interfaces: callback and promise
To use the callback interface: do not return a promise
To use the promise interface: remove the last argument to the function
```

title: Upgrade to cucumber-expressions 4.0.0
body:
This PR upgrades to [Cucumber Expressions 4.0.0](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/cucumber-expressions/CHANGELOG.md#400---2017-06-27)

There are backwards incompatible changes in this release, which might warrant a major version bump in cucumber-js too:

## Parameter types must be defined

Using an `{undefined}` parameter type will result in an error. This may sound like a hassle, but the benefits outweigh the drawbacks in my opinion.

Forcing users to define parameter types encourages the evolution of a ubiquitous language.

## New `{word}` and `{string}` parameter types

The `{word}` type is handy to use instead of old `{undefined}` ones.
The `{string}` type replaces the old `{stringInDoubleQuotes}` one, and works with both single and double quotes

## Parameter types can use the same regex

This used to cause errors in previous releases. Because they are now allowed, each undefined step
can result in several possible cucumber expressions for snippets, as outlined in https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/issues/132.

For this reason, the `CucumberExpressionGenerator.generateExpression` method is deprecated in favour of `CucumberExpressionGenerator.generateExpressions`, which returns a list of `GeneratedExpression` (the one at index 0 is the one the user is most likely to want).

So before this PR is merged, it should be updated to use the new method, and display all expressions when printing snippets. As discussed with @charlierudolph at cukeup, we're not sure how to best do that. Let's discuss some possible output examples in this issue before proceeding.

title: use prettier
undefined steps should always fail the test run
body:
Based off discussion in https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/442

The following was an argument for ambiguous steps to cause the test run to fail

> consider a scenario which is passing. One of its steps suddenly becomes ambiguous because of a new step definition. That scenario will be reported as ambiguous, which is not considered a failure (Cucumber's return code is still 0). Let's assume the behaviour described in that scenario was modified and got broken recently. It is now possible that nobody will pay attention to it: the build is still green but in fact that piece of behaviour is not tested anymore and is broken.

I think this should be extended to undefined in the case that a step definition is deleted by accident or during a refactoring when it changes and a step is no longer matched. I also consider undefined and ambiguous steps similar cases as in both, cucumber-js could not find what step definition to run.

This leaves pending as the only type of step that can keep the build green in non-strict mode. That at least requires an explicit syntax and is thus less likely to happen by accident.

title: pretty errors
body:
This removes the pretty formatter but outputs errors in pretty format. Thus 
failed/ambiguous/pending/undefined scenarios will be pretty printed but passing scenarios will not.

This is a breaking change as it removes the pretty formatter and changes the interface of a formatter helper. Both of these are exposed in case someone wanted to use them for custom formatters.

title: Spike functional API
body:
This is a spike of a possible functional API for stepdefs (and hooks) (potential solution for #745). I didn't bother figuring out how to expose the helpers on a submodule (`cucumber/fn`), but that would be nicer than the `fn`-prefixed helpers.

The way I dealt with the number or arguments in stepdefs is quite ugly but was good enough to demonstrate the functional interface.

Thoughts?

title: defineParameterType cannot handle regexp with groups for regexp step definition
body:
On CucumberJS 2.2:
TL;DR - When working with RegExp steps, parameters with inner groups aren't processed by the matching parameter types.

Steps to reproduce (exact code provided below):
1. Define a step using regexp with a parameter that includes inner non-capturing groups.
2. Define a parameter type tracking this parameter.

The parameter type transform function doesn't execute.

Reproduce with the following scenarios (to be added to `/features/parameter_types.feature`):

**Demonstrate the bug itself (will fail)**:
```
Scenario: transform regexp with groups
    Given a file named "features/demo_steps.feature" with:
      """
      Feature: a feature
        Scenario: a scenario
          Given a demo step
      """
    Given a file named "features/step_definitions/my_steps.js" with:
      """
      import assert from 'assert'
      import {defineSupportCode} from 'cucumber'

      defineSupportCode(({Given}) => {
        Given(/a (demo(?:nstration)?) step/, function(param) {
          assert.equal(param, 'DEMO')
        })
      })
      """
    Given a file named "features/support/transforms.js" with:
      """
      import {defineSupportCode} from 'cucumber'

      defineSupportCode(({defineParameterType}) => {
        defineParameterType({
          regexp: /demo(?:nstration)?/,
          transformer: s => s.toUpperCase(),
          typeName: 'param'
        })
      })
      """
    When I run cucumber.js
    Then the step "a demo step" has status "passed"
```

**Demonstrate the bug doesn't occur without capture groups (will pass)**:
```
Scenario: transform without groups
    Given a file named "features/demo_steps.feature" with:
      """
      Feature: a feature
        Scenario: a scenario
          Given a demo step
      """
    Given a file named "features/step_definitions/my_steps.js" with:
      """
      import assert from 'assert'
      import {defineSupportCode} from 'cucumber'

      defineSupportCode(({Given}) => {
        Given(/a (demo|demonstration) step/, function(param) {
          assert.equal(param, 'DEMO')
        })
      })
      """
    Given a file named "features/support/transforms.js" with:
      """
      import {defineSupportCode} from 'cucumber'

      defineSupportCode(({defineParameterType}) => {
        defineParameterType({
          regexp: /demo|demonstration/,
          transformer: s => s.toUpperCase(),
          typeName: 'param'
        })
      })
      """
    When I run cucumber.js
    Then the step "a demo step" has status "passed"
```

**Demonstrate the bug doesn't occur with cucumber expressions (will pass)**:

```
 Scenario: transform expression with groups
    Given a file named "features/demo_steps.feature" with:
      """
      Feature: a feature
        Scenario: a scenario
          Given a demo step
      """
    Given a file named "features/step_definitions/my_steps.js" with:
      """
      import assert from 'assert'
      import {defineSupportCode} from 'cucumber'

      defineSupportCode(({Given}) => {
        Given('a {param} step', function(param) {
          assert.equal(param, 'DEMO')
        })
      })
      """
    Given a file named "features/support/transforms.js" with:
      """
      import {defineSupportCode} from 'cucumber'

      defineSupportCode(({defineParameterType}) => {
        defineParameterType({
          regexp: /demo(?:nstration)?/,
          transformer: s => s.toUpperCase(),
          typeName: 'param'
        })
      })
      """
    When I run cucumber.js
    Then the step "a demo step" has status "passed"
```

Then the snippet with no forward slash in it will match
And the snippet with a forward slash in it will not match

Notes: This is version 2.2.0. The output snippets use strings; turning it into a RegEx (and escaping the forward slash) is one way to solve this issue.

title: Tags example in Changelog of 2.0.0-rc.0 not correct
body:
In the [Changelog of 2.0.0-rc.0](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#200-rc0-2016-11-25) the changes in the tags are explained. I see the example `--tags @foo --tags @bar` becomes `--tags '@foo and bar'` and according to what I understand this isn't correct. It should be `--tags @foo --tags @bar` becomes `--tags '@foo and @bar'`, so an `@` for `bar`.

I do see it correct in the [hooks](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/master/docs/support_files/hooks.md) documentation.

What's the best way to fix this? Can I create a PR for the Changelog?

title: Feature request: Add a SystemJs module loader option
body:
Use case:
Green field project. BDD all the way! Yey! Ok, cool.... so, cucumberjs has been chosen to help out (ignore any BDD theory discussions here please). We have js being used on both the client and server side. On the client side, we have (View/ViewModel/Model etc) separation of concerns in our classes all done nicely (using typescript but that's irrelevant) and systemJs as our module loader (used by aurelia in this case).

I don't want to jump into 'use jasmine etc' for unit tests and cucumber for e2e tests, as I think this is looking at it the wrong way around. I want to start with cucumber for everything and only if I feel there's a need, use jasmine etc for specific purposes. Aside, I've seen far too many projects with a 'definition' in feature files and a different 'definition' written in jasmine specs.

-- 

AFAIK this isn't possible, as node loads the cucumber step definitions and that's that. Can this be changed so that systemJs could load the modules?

To be explicit: On a test-by-test basis I want to have a test case in a feature file and decide to check it in the browser (traditional e2e cucumber-protractor testing), or in node (more akin to unit testing). This is made possible by testing non-browser dependent features and would commonly test ViewModels/DomainModels etc.

I appreciate that this would require running cucumber twice with the different configurations but that is ok by me, and I expect to tag the scenarios with 'ui' in, for example, browser tests, of which I hope to have very few.

Is this easy to do? Likely to be done soon? I'm happy to look at creating a PR if you can point me in the right direction.

Thanks,
John

title: pass the step definition options to function wrapper
body:
It would be helpful to have the options available in the wrapper.
Then I can do something like this:

```javascript
defineSupportCode(function ({setDefinitionFunctionWrapper}) {
    setDefinitionFunctionWrapper(function (fn, options) {
        let retryTest = isFinite(options.retry) ? parseInt(options.retry, 10) : 0
        let wrappedFunction = isAsync(fn) || config.sync === false
            ? wrapStepAsync(fn, retryTest) : wrapStepSync(fn, retryTest)
        return wrappedFunction
    })
})
```

I'm currently writing a "wdio-cucumber2-framework" (which is a wrapper around cucumber 2 to allow webdriverio runner run cucumber tests), and this is the cleanest way for me to implement retrying (this is how it was done in wdio-cucumber-framework as well , with the options)

Please let me know what you think, I hope you don't feel like this is too much of a feature creep. :-) 

Thanks!

title: RegularExpression constructor is not filtering non-capturing groups
body:
Hi there,

It seems like there is a bug in the RegularExpression class in the cucumber-expressions dependency.
The regex in this constructor looks for capturing groups when processing steps using the regex:

 `/\(([^(]+)\)/g`

This regex finds everything between braces (a.k.a. capturing groups), but it also accepts non-capturing groups. This causes the constructor to generate parameter types for the non capturing groups (instead of the capturing groups only). 

These parameter types are used in the buildArguments function, but are only applied to capturing groups, since the given step regex filters out the non-capturing groups correctly.

I would expect the RegularExpression constructor to filter out these capturing groups correctly.

The step and step definitions I used to reproduce the issue are:

Step:
`I can cancel the 1st slide upload`

Step definition:
`(\S+) ?(can|cannot)? (?:delete|cancel) the (\d+)(?:st|nd|rd|th) (attachment|slide) ?(?:upload)?`

In this case 7 parameter types are being generated by the constructor, while it should only create 4, since 3 of them are non-capturing groups. As a result, the parameter type that belongs to (\d+) is being applied to (attachment|slide), treating it as an integer. This results into a NaN value that is being passed to my step definition.

Version info:

- Cucumberjs: 2.1.0
- Node: v6.9.1
- Npm: 3.10.8

title: WIP: feat(support-code): Allow direct import
body:
Allow direct import of support code:

```javascript
const { 
  Given,
  When,
  Then,
  Before,
  After,
  defineParameterType, 
  addTransform, 
  defineStep, 
  registerHandler, 
  registerListener, 
  setDefaultTimeout, 
  setDefinitionFunctionWrapper, 
  setWorldConstructor 
} = require('cucumber');
```

Todo:
- [ ] Decide if we're keeping the `defineSupportCode`
- [ ] Update all feature files (or write new ones, if we decide to keep `defineSupportCode`)
- [ ] Update all docs (or add to the existing docs of we decide to keep `defineSupportCode`)

I personally think that its better to not export `defineSupportCode` from `cucumber` anymore. It will simplify the docs and features. I know there will initially be a pain for existing code that would need to be rewritten, but it will be much simpler in the end.

Note: related PR #828 was my first attempt.

Fixes issue #770

title: I failed to find any solution to ignore certain files extensions from transpilation, while using cucucmber-cli
body:
Hello. 

In my case: `"cucumberjs --compiler js:babel-register",` was throwing an error, because we are using [css-modules](https://github.com/css-modules/css-modules) - this makes babel-register fail, unless there is a way to exclude the css files from transpilation. 

I was able to implement some solution, and will be glad to hear from you what you think about it.

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/pull/829

title: added solution to exclude certain files extensions from compilation
WIP: feat(support-code): Import support code from `'cucumber'` directly
body:
Make it possible to do this:

```javascript
const {given, when, then} = require('cucumber');
```

This is a work in progress.

I've hacked in the functionality without (hopefully) breaking the `const { defineSupportCode } = require('cucumber');` construct. However i think this solution gets a bit messy.
1. It can get complicated for an end user if you have multiple ways of doing things.
2. It gets complicated in the code, especially in the `support_code_fns.js` and `helpers.js`. 

If we drop the support for `defineSupportCode` we can cleanup the code further and simplify a lot of things INHO. For example, we can simplify the `support_code_libary/helpers.js`, `support_code_library/builder.js` and `support_code_fns.js`.  Also it would be possible to import all the functions like `addTransform`, `defineParameterType`, `registerHandler`, `registerListener`, `setDefaultTimeout`, `    setDefinitionFunctionWrapper`and `setWorldConstructor` directly from `'cucumber'`, which would simplify the usage even further.

Do you agree on this approach? It would mean rewriting the examples and test feature files.

Note: I haven't been able to run the features locally because of #826 

Fixes #770

title: Document lack of arrow function support in step definitions
body: It's common these days to use es6 arrow functions by default. However, in step definitions they break the concept of `world` being stored in `this`. Which is fair enough, but perhaps this fact deserves a line in a readme to save newcomers some head scratching.

title: Improve documentation about common step definition scoping patterns & 'use strict'
body:
As of now, if you happen enable _strict mode_ in a step definitions, nothing seems to work as expected, irrespective of whether or not you declare the `defineSupportCode` callback with a fatarrow or not.

Perhaps it could be a wee bit better explained exactly _what_ is being passed in to the `defineSupportCode` callback and how you may get a good tradeoff between sane amount of boilerplate code and step definition readability.

I also think we should keep in mind that some users might still not be able to use late ES6 features such object destructuring assignment of function parameters and/or will add `'strict mode'` out of habit / editor snippets.

title: Update step_definitions.md
body:
The whole idea of the [webdriver control flow](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/wiki/WebDriverJs) is that asynchronous tasks can be written in a synchronous way, implicitly executing each promise when the one queued before is fullfiled.

This style mix very well with cucumber.js and should be encouraged. All that is needed is to return the last promise at the end of a step.

title: Option to "fail fast" on BeforeFeatures catastrophic failure
body:
While I don't want to use the --fail-fast behaviour (i.e., I want all the tests that could run, to run, regardless of previous failures), I *do* want to "fail fast" if the BeforeFeatures hook fails (since that means something very fundamental in my env. setup has failed).

A quick and dirty way to achieve a similar practical result could be for BeforeFeatures to be able to flip the --fail-fast switch, so that the first step run will be the last. A better solution would be for a promise rejection from that hook to immediately fail the run, regardless of the fail fast flag.

What do you think?

title: Non Capture Group Transform
body:
### The Need:

There are many cases in our step definitions where we have a varity of repeated groups that don't change the steps functionality, but does do quite a bit for readablilty in the feature files:

* "must"/"should"
* optional words like "the", "I" etc that would match `Given I fill in "Foo"` & `And fill in "Bar"`
* lists of interchangable words

### How I would implement it

Perhaps square brackets could be used for things that don't need to be captured, but still require the transformation, which would save time in having to re-write your captures for non-capture functionality.

```
Given('[pronoun] ha(ve|s) {int} child(|ren)', (children) => {
// Code
})
```
Could match

```gherkin
 Given I have 3 children
 Given he has 4 children
 Given she has 1 child
```

For simplification purposes, I think this would be great, as if you needed to add something to the non-capture transform (in the use-case above, adding "they", or "Jeff"), this could then be used across the board without having to edit all the step definitions that would use this transform.

What are your thoughts on both usefulness, and ease of actually making this a possibility?

Catch parameter transform errors
body: This is a fix for #765. It depends on #764 and is branched off from the `cucumber-expressions-2.0.0` branch.

title: Throwing an error from a transform function kills Cucumber
body:
How to reproduce:

```javascript
addTransform({
  captureGroupRegexps: ['[A-Z]\\w+'],
  transformer: s =>  { throw new Error('I killed cucumber') },
  typeName: 'name'
})
```

title: Upgrade to Cucumber Expressions 3.0.0
body:
This PR upgrades to [Cucumber Expressions 3.0.0](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/cucumber-expressions/CHANGELOG.md#200---2017-02-17), which has several improvements.

This PR also removes the custom logic to compute parameter names in snippet functions, and uses the logic provided by the cucumber-expressions library instead.

title: update profile configuration file
body:
Current `cucumber.js` file
```js
var common = [
  '--compiler js:babel-register',
  '--format progress',
  '--format rerun:@rerun.txt',
  '--format usage:usage.txt'
].join(' ')

module.exports = {
  'default': common,
  'node-4': common + ' --tags "not @node-6"',
};
```
Suggested update new `cucumber.yml` file (using references)
```yml
_common: &COMMON
  compiler: js:babel-register
  format:
    - progress
    - rerun:@rerun.txt
    - usage:usage.txt

default:
  <<: *COMMON

node-4:
  <<: *COMMON
  tags: not @node-6
```

@jbpros thoughts? We originally went with `.js` in order to avoid the clash with ruby's `cucumber.yml` but I don't see think thats as an issue. Aside from this project when I first joined, I've never seen a project that used both `cucumber-ruby` and `cucumber-js`. Nor can I think of a valid reason to do so.

@mattwynne you as well as you may be able to get rid of the erb support. 

Mainly would like to allow users to not have put actual CLI options in here. The options mirror the long form of the CLI options but without the need of actually specifying them with all the `--`. Implementation wise you can still convert these to cli options pretty easily (on the javascript side the there is a javascript library for doing that: [dargs](https://github.com/sindresorhus/dargs).

body:
In order to attract newcomers to contribute, we should help them where to start.
Whenever you see a new issue, and you think it is a good fit for someone who isn't familiar with the codebase, tag it with `newcomers`.

All newcomers friendly issues in the cucumber org can be listed [here](https://github.com/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+user%3Acucumber+label%3Anewcomers+no%3Aassignee+) - we'll link to that from our yet-to-be-written "How to contribute" page on our website.

This is an ongoing effort, but what you can do right now is to have a scan at existing issues, tag a few of them. Then close this issue.

title: Generated step definition snippets are not found
body:
I'm running `2.0.0-rc.6`

Given a feature file:
```
Scenario: In range shout is heard
    Given Lucy is at [0, 0]
    And Sean is at [0, 900]
    When Sean shouts
    Then Lucy should hear Sean
```

When I run cucumberjs, it outputs the following snippet:
```
Step: Given Lucy is at [0, 0] - features/hear_shout.feature:6
   Message:
     Undefined. Implement with the following snippet:

       Given('Lucy is at [{arg1:int}, {arg2:int}]', function (arg1, arg2, callback) {
         // Write code here that turns the phrase above into concrete actions
         callback(null, 'pending');
       });
```

When I add the snippet in a step definitions file, the method is not called/found.  The same output above is produced.

But, re-writing the step definition to use regular expression:
```
Given(/^Lucy is at \[(\d+), (\d+)\]$/, function (x, y, callback) {
    callback(null, 'pending');
  });
```

Then step is found, and marked as pending (expected output)
```
Step: Given Lucy is at [0, 0] - features/hear_shout.feature:6
   Step Definition: features/step_definitions/shout_steps.js:10
   Message:
     Pending
```

title: Provide Cucumber Typescript definitions within this package
body:
As of right now, the cucumber-js [typescript definitions](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/tree/master/cucumber) are defined in the [DefinitelyTyped](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped) repository.


A typescript user that wants to use cucumber-js must have both cucumber and @types/cucumber in their dependencies. Providing the definitions within this package eliminate the need to install the @types/cucumber package. 

Also, it would be easier to track the changes needed in the typescript definitions when the cucumber-js API changes. Furthermore, since cucumber-js contributors know well the API, they could provide helpful advices to people that want to update/correct the typescript definitions.

There is currently an open issue on the DefinitelyTyped repo to remove packages that provides their own definitions (https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/issues/13364), so I think this is a normal path to adopt.

title: support code library: interface change
body:
Currently for any support file, it if exports a function, the function is called. This is not ideal because in javascript classes are functions and if you have a support file that exports a class it will be run. This is not desired and will sometimes error due to the constructor expecting parameters or if the class verifies it is only called with new.

@aslakhellesoy @mattwynne can you explain how your cucumber versions load support files and plusses / minuses you have seen so far?

title: Support pendingReason
Allow absolute paths to compiler modules on windows
body:
In order to provide more complex options for babel-register as a compiler, I need to wrap the require for babel-register providing appropriate options.

However, this breaks the current implementation of `--compiler` on Windows, as `js:C:\...` contains multiple `:`s.

This change allows the specification of an absolute path to compiler on Windows.

title: Hooks don't catch Promise rejections

# features/something.feature
Feature: thing

Scenario: Something
  Given stuff

```

And:

```javascript
// features/step_definitions.js
module.exports = function() {
  this.BeforeFeatures(() => Promise.reject());
  this.defineStep(/^stuff$/, () => Promise.resolve());
};
```

The console outputs:

```
(node:3197) UnhandledPromiseRejectionWarning: Unhandled promise rejection (rejection id: 2): node_modules/cucumber/lib/cucumber/support_code/library.js:17 Promise rejected
```

I get the same behavior for the other hooks. In my actual project, often the test runner also hangs on such rejections.

title: setTimeout causing double step execution
body:
I was messing around with `setTimeout` at `0ms` to try testing promises and see if that would fix some issues I was having. When surrounding `next()` with `setTimeout`, I noticed some very strange behavior. It runs the test twice!

This is how you'd normally console log and then go to the next line.

``` js
this.When("Hello World!", next => {
    console.log('hi')
    next()
})
```

When `setTimeout` is used wrapping `next()`, then it double-fires this test. Very strange!

``` js
this.When("Hello World!", next => {
    console.log('hi')
    setTimeout(() => next(), 0)
})
```

I keep thinking maybe my JS is bad, but it's looking fine. I originally thought it had to do with promises, but it seems to do it with any timeout code. Console logging time differences, it's was obvious to me this is executing the test than once.

What's going on here?

title: Issues with Protractor and `process.uncaughtException`
body:
Hi there,

> this is not quite an issue, more of a discussion. Please let me know if there's a more helpful venue for this

We've had some [issues](https://github.com/angular/protractor/issues/3553#issuecomment-248898275) on Protractor about removing our usage of [`process.on('uncaughtException')`](https://github.com/cnishina/protractor/blob/4b54ec8449a570459e51caf6cc6ccae4b5c16b12/lib/launcher.ts#L180) because it clobbers the cucumber [`uncaughtExceptionErrorHandler`](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/master/lib/cucumber/util/exception.js#L6). 

This is a bit of a difficult issue because both projects expect to be the "end of the line". This is similar with other frameworks like [mocha](https://github.com/mochajs/mocha/blob/master/lib/runner.js#L824). Unfortunately, there seems to be a disconnect with handling certain types of exceptions in cucumber that does not present itself in Mocha. 

Is there a way we could work together to figure something out? Ideally both projects could play nicely without compromising the ability to safely recover from errors.

I'm happy to help and coordinate from the protractor side.

    return this.driver.sleep(numSeconds * 1000);
});
```

But it doesn't work.  If I have that step and one after it:

```

```

I see the log from the second step immediately, not 20 seconds later:

a message

Is there an alternate way to express "wait 20 seconds" in Cucumber, or is this a bug?

title: Set timeout in formatter events
Possible to get table cell strings with leading/trailing spaces?
body:
The OSRM route engine uses tables to define small 'maps' of node locations used in tests, ie:

``` gherkin
            |   |   | a |   |   |
            |   |   | b |   |   |
            | d | c |   | g | h |
            |   |   | e |   |   |
            |   |   | f |   |   |
```

The horizontal and vertical position of nodes are translated to latitude and longitude. This might be a somewhat unusual use of tables, but it's very useful.

To make the maps easier to read I would like simplify the syntax to:

``` gherkin
            |     a     |
            |     b     |
            | d c   g h |
            |     e     |
            |     f     |
```

However cucumber strips leading (and trailing) spaces from the cell strings, ie. "    a    " is returned as "a", which breaks the horizontal positions.

Is there any way to get the raw strings including the leading spaces?

I guess we could quote all lines, but this is awkward. I looked at transforms, but it seems cucumber js doesn't implement it, and anyways I'm not sure it would solve the problem?

Thanks!

title: Minor Issue: No Way to Continue After a Debugger
body:
When I use Cucumber.js I run it through Node so that I can enable debugging mode:

```
nodejs --debug ./node_modules/.bin/cucumber.js test/cucumber
```

For the most part that works great: I can do:

```
this.Then('I pause', () => {
    debugger;
});
```

and add:

```
I pause
```

anywhere in my tests to freeze the test execution and look at what's on the screen.

There's only one, relatively minor, problem: after the pause I have to `CTRL + C` out of the test, because there's no way to continue.  Normally when running Node in debug mode if you hit a debugger line you can proceed by hitting `c`, but for some reason that doesn't work with Cucumber.

It's not a big deal, because when you want to pause like that you're debugging, and so having to stop/re-run the test isn't a huge problem.  But if it's an easy fix, it would be nice if you could keep going through the test after a `debugger` (and if it's not then this should probably be closed as a "won't fix").

title: spreading args with regex
CLI doesn't load '--require' files/directories in order specified
body:
For example with this command:

```
cucumberjs \
  --require node_modules/coffee-coverage/register-istanbul.js \
  --require $path_root/features \
  --compiler coffee:coffee-script/register $*
```

The apparent loading order is:
1. `$path_root/features/support/*` files
2. `node_modules/coffee-coverage/register-istanbul.js`

Renaming the `support` directory to `hooks` seems to work around the problem acceptably.

title: Add support for Tag Expressions
body:
## Summary

[Tag Expressions](http://docs.cucumber.io/tag-expressions/) is a more intuitive way to specify tags in tagged hooks and on the command line's `--tags` argument.
## Expected Behavior

Tagged Hooks should accept a single string:

``` JavaScript
Before("@foo and not @bar", function() {
})
```

Likewise, the `--tags` command line argument should allow the same. (Specifying it more than once should cause an error)

```
--tags "@foo and not @bar"
```
## Context & Motivation

The current mechanism to specify `or` with comma and `and` with multiple `--tags` is incredibly awkward. Tag Expressions are intuitive!

title: Add support for Cucumber Expressions
body:
## Summary

[Cucumber Expressions](http://docs.cucumber.io/cucumber-expressions/) is a new alternative to
Regular Expressions, which is easier to read and write, and less daunting.
## Expected Behavior

<!--- If you're describing a bug, tell us what should happen -->

<!--- If you're suggesting a change/improvement, tell us how it should work -->

<!--- Feel free to use Given / Then / Then if that helps, but please add some plain-language context too -->

Step Defintions defined with a `String` (and not a `Regexp`) should be interpreted as a Cucumber Expression:

``` JavaScript
Given("I have {n:int} cukes in my belly", function(cukeCount) {
  // It's already converted to a number
  assert.equal(typeof cukeCount, 'number')
})
```

Likewise, if a Regular Expression is used (old school):

``` javascript
Given(/I have (\d+) cukes in my belly/, function(cukeCount) {
  // It's already converted to a number
  assert.equal(typeof cukeCount, 'number')
})
```

This is possible because the `cucumber-expression` library's `RegExp` support takes advantage of type conversions too.

Snippets for undefined steps should use Cucumber Expressions, and not Regular Expressions. We want users to start migrating, and if we can avoid it we'll not generate snippets with regular expressions. (Well, we might if enough people want it). The `cucumber-expression` library can already generate expressions from text.

Finally, the current `Transform` logic should be deprecated and the logic built into the `cucumber-expression` library should be used instead.
## Context & Motivation

Having to use Regular Expressions is one of the most common complaints against Cucumber. Other clones of Cucumber who support something similar to Cucumber Expressions seem to have happier users!

title: Feature Hook not accepting tags
If a scenario has no description, the json should put empty strings in scenario description
body:
Referring to [Cucumber's json output formatter](https://www.relishapp.com/cucumber/cucumber/docs/formatters/json-output-formatter), a scenario element will always have a description attribute, with an empty string if there is no description:

```
{
        "keyword": "Scenario",
        "id": "one-passing-scenario,-one-failing-scenario;passing",
        "name": "Passing",
        "line": 5,
        "description": "",
....
```

Instead, cucumber-js seems to [omit the description](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/master/features/json_formatter.feature) when it is missing in the feature. Some reporting tools like cukedoctor are [not able to handle JSON with this field missing](https://github.com/rmpestano/cukedoctor/issues/66). The correct thing to do, I'm guessing looking at the Cucumber spec linked above, is to always in include scenario description.

title: stack_trace_filter no longer blows up when given an error object without a stack trace
body:
When an asynchronous test step returns a promise rejected with an `Error` (`AssertionError` in the case of Chai), such as:

``` javascript
return expect(browser.getTitle()).to.eventually.equal('my website')
```

Cucumber produces the following error output:

```
/Users/jan/project/node_modules/cucumber/lib/cucumber/runtime/stack_trace_filter.js:9
  var fileName = frame.getFileName() || '';
                      ^
TypeError: node_modules/protractor-cucumber-framework/lib/resultsCapturer.js:60 Cannot read property 'getFileName' of undefined
    at isFrameInCucumber (/Users/jan/project/node_modules/cucumber/lib/cucumber/runtime/stack_trace_filter.js:9:23)
    at Array.<anonymous> (/Users/jan/project/node_modules/cucumber/lib/cucumber/runtime/stack_trace_filter.js:15:9)
    at TraceModifier._modify (/Users/jan/project/node_modules/cucumber/node_modules/stack-chain/stack-chain.js:44:32)
    at Function.prepareStackTrace (/Users/jan/project/node_modules/cucumber/node_modules/stack-chain/stack-chain.js:119:25)
    at /Users/jan/project/node_modules/protractor-cucumber-framework/lib/resultsCapturer.js:73:37
    at Object.run (/Users/jan/project/node_modules/cucumber/lib/cucumber/util/run.js:34:19)
    at Object.hear (/Users/jan/project/node_modules/cucumber/lib/cucumber/listener.js:15:23)
    at /Users/jan/project/node_modules/cucumber/lib/cucumber/runtime/event_broadcaster.js:28:18
    at iterate (/Users/jan/project/node_modules/cucumber/lib/cucumber/util/async_for_each.js:7:7)
    at nextTickCallbackWith0Args (node.js:420:9)
```

This is caused by an assumption made in the `stack_trace_filterer` that an instance of an `Error` will always have a stack trace associated with it.

This pull request adds a check to verify that the stack trace is not empty.

title: How to stop test running at first failure?
Runtime.getSupportCodeLibrary returns a new instance
body:
Requirement:
We are implementing a wrapper around cucumberjs to speedup the testing process across the company.  We have a requirement to allow for step definitions to call other step definitions as discussed [here](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/11).  To support this we are dynamically adding new steps before the feature runs using the support code library defineStep(...).

Issue:
The runtime offers access to the support code library retrieving it from the configuration.  But each time it it is retrieved a new instance is returned.

I would expect this to be tied to the runtime instance so once it is retrieved we return the same instance.

Please let me know if this seems reasonable, I'm happy to make the change and test it.

title: New "function accepts a callback and returns a promise" errors
body:
It looks like the latest updates (1.1.0) and (1.2.0) may have introduced a breaking change.  The `registerHandler` now prevents returning a promise and using a callback.  So coffeescript constructions such as

```
  @registerHandler 'AfterFeatures', (event, done) ->
    teardownDb()
    .then -> done()
```

will now break.  This is easily fixed by removing the last line or returning `null`.  However this broke our builds without warning since our package setting was `^1.0.0`.

Possibly this should be a deprecation warning instead of an error.

title: Proper handling of tagged hook options
body:
Hey guys,

I tried following the [tagged hooks](https://github.com/MrSenko/cucumber-js#tagged-hooks) example from the documentation but I got:

```
/Users/krasimir/Work/TrialReach/projects/gargantua/node_modules/cucumber/lib/cucumber/tag_group_parser.js:4
      var splitTags = tagGroupString.split(TagGroupParser.TAG_SEPARATOR);
```

It looks like in `lib/cucumber/tag_group_parser.js` `tagGroupString` is actually not a string anymore. It comes as an object in the shape of:

```
{ tags: [ '@regression' ] }
```

So I added a simple check to transform that object into a string.

title: Hooks Before is not called
Fix typo in event name.
native base64 encoding, fix for binary attachments
body:
this removes the `base-64` dependency which doesn't support binary input (it throws an error if input is not ASCII), that makes json formatter fail if any attachment is binary (like screenshots are), replacing it node.js native base64 encoding.
as a side benefit, native encoding is probably (not measure) faster, and it's one less dependency to care about.

title: Can't set formatter output file on Windows
body:
Hello,

Currently there is an option to configure an output file for a formatter.

```
format: ['pretty', 'json: logfile.json' ]
```

Using an absolute path on Windows causes a problem because of the colon syntax.
The problem is with using the split method as Windows machines have colon in the path. (C:\Users...)
https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/master/lib/cucumber/cli/configuration.js#L46

So the following configuration will output to a file with name `C` :)

```
format: ['pretty', 'json: C:\Temp\log123.json' ]
```

Thanks
Igor

title: Cli.run callback is not called when cucumber-js itself fails
body:
This issue repro's when another issue such as this one occurs https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/564

See problem 2 in https://github.com/efokschaner/cucumber-js-fails-when-step-error-is-not-exception for a full write up, summarized here:

When cucumber-js has an internal error, it does not call the callback passed to `Cli.run`, leaving the caller unaware of failure. With blocking or callback steps this causes an unhandled exception. With Promise steps, this causes an unhandled rejection, which is not fatal and can leave the program hanging. As an example of real impact, this affects the following project: https://github.com/midniteio/multi-cuke/blob/v0.6.5/src/lib/worker.js where it performs multiple `cucumber.Cli` runs in forked node processes to parallelise testing. When the unhandled rejection occurs the worker does not know that cucumber has stopped executing.

title: Cucumber json formatter throws when step error is not Error or JSON.stringify'able
body:
See https://github.com/efokschaner/cucumber-js-fails-when-step-error-is-not-exception for a repro and full write up, summarized here:

In general Cucumber seems to assume that the error from a step is always an Error or a string but this is not documented or enforced anywhere. In cucumber 0.9.5 and 0.10.2 the JSON formatter specifically assumes the object is an Error or is JSON.stringify'able. This happens at https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/v0.10.2/lib/cucumber/listener/json_formatter.js#L147 The gherkinJsonFormatter ultimately calls JSON.stringify on stepOutput.error_message.

In v0.9 a related issue affects the pretty formatter, which got accidentally fixed in 0.10 but the underlying risk remains.

I propose we coerce the error's type as soon as it comes from the step, at https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/v0.10.2/lib/cucumber/support_code/step_definition.js#L75, this allows the type returned by stepResult.getFailureException() to always be an exception or string. If this solution seems reasonable I'll open a PR.

title: Feature with undefined Background: step errors with "TypeError: Cannot read property 'getUri' of undefined" in v0.10.1
body:
I recently updated to 0.10.1 and found that my cucumber scripts started to fail with an error.  Eventually narrowed it down to having a Background: section with an undefined step.

Using the following feature file (in the right directory this time <ahem>):

```
bash-3.2$ cat features/background.feature 
Feature: A funny old thing

Background:

    Given an undefined background step

Scenario: Bing bang bosh

    Given cucumber v0.10.1
    When used against this feature
    Then it tries to call getUri on an undefined var
```

Gives me the following error:

```
bash-3.2$ node_modules/.bin/cucumber.js 
Feature: A funny old thing

  Scenario: Bing bang bosh
    Given an undefined background step
    Given cucumber v0.10.1
    When used against this feature
    Then it tries to call getUri on an undefined var

/private/tmp/cuke0.10.1/node_modules/cucumber/lib/cucumber/listener/summary_formatter.js:151
    var scenarioLocation = path.relative(process.cwd(), scenario.getUri()) + ':' + scenario.getLine();
                                                                ^

TypeError: Cannot read property 'getUri' of undefined
    at Array.forEach (native)
```

This is fine under 0.9.5 and also works if I remove the step from the Background: section

title: Fail message and stack no longer visible from default formatter
body:
When a test fail, we used to see the reason and stack just below the red line in version `0.9.5`.

Now that I've updated to `0.10.1` the reason is only summarized at the end. That's great and nice, but it was very helpful to see the errors as they were appearing, so we don't need to wait for x minutes before we know what to work on.

Is there any work around that? Could it be an option, a formatter, etc.? Thanks

title: --focus flag
body:
@kevgo thoughts on the following to better support your workflow which may be disrupted by #521

Using the existing rerun functionality, but with a new `--focus` flag, it will run only the first feature your the rerun file. If the test passes, it is removed from the rerun file, otherwise the rerun file is left unchanged. 

Example:

```
> cucumber-js
Scenarios A, B, and C fail
Scenarios D, E, and F pass

> cucumber-js @rerun.txt
Only runs scenarios A, B, and C (which fail)

> cucumber-js --focus @rerun.txt
Only runs scenario A (which fails)

# Fix Failure A

> cucumber-js --focus @rerun.txt
Only runs scenario A (which passes)

> cucumber-js --focus @rerun.txt
Only runs scenario B (which fails)

# Fix Failure B

> cucumber-js --focus @rerun.txt
Only runs scenario B (which passes)

> cucumber-js --focus @rerun.txt
Only runs scenario C (which fails)

# Fix Failure C

> cucumber-js --focus @rerun.txt
Only runs scenario C (which passes)

> cucumber-js --focus @rerun.txt
Reruns the whole test suite because your @rerun.txt file is empty 
```

title: ability to set timeout within step function body
body:
sometimes we wish to have a dynamically determined timeout, such as one expressed within the Gherkin itself and matched on; or sometimes based on some other dynamic behavior that occurs within the step definition function body itself.

I propose something like callback.timeout(10000), which would have to be called before any default timeout (global or as 2nd param to the step definition {timeout:x} form). If it is set before that, then the default timeout is cancelled and a new timeout set where the timer starts at that instant.

The other thing is that in IntelliJ the plugin does not work when the { timeout: x } 2nd param is used, and one cannot jump from Gherkin to the step definition. Solving for dynamic timeout would indirectly create a workaround for the plugin deficiency.

body:
Tech Stack: 

Cucumber: 0.9.4
Angular: 1.5
Protractor: 2.5.1
Chai: ^2.2.0
Chai-As-Promised: ^5.1.0

I have recently started to see some strange behavior in my tests, and I was hoping to get this resolved whether it is something I am doing, or an issue somewhere in my tech stack. In my assertion steps sometimes I have a several assertions happening in which I use chai-as-promise, and I always return just the last assertion. Recently I am seeing depending on the scenarios I run and if the step passes that has a bulk of promises in it or a bulk of assertions in it that sometimes those promises are getting resolved later on in other scenarios and failing other scenarios with selectors that are coming from steps that were run scenarios before. My question is, is there something I can be doing different, or is this an issue in the tech stack, because I didnt seem to have these issues prior to Angular 1.4. So my thinking is somehow that upgrade doesnt work nicely with the cucumber. I would really like some clarification into this issue, so if you need more information or more example I would be happy to provide them. Thank you in advance. 

Some more info I found later today: [cucumber-chai-wd](https://github.com/sebsorin/cucumber-chai-wd) , I havent had the opportunity to try this yet. But I was wondering if this is absolutely necessary as I thought cucumber was handling this already?

Support organizing .feature files into subdirectories of "features"
body:
Cucumber-Ruby allows to organize `.feature` files into subdirectories of `/features`. This structure is useful for example when using folders for epics, and then one `feature` file per feature of that epic. 

Cucumber-JS doesn't seem to support this fully. 
- running `cucumber-js features/run.feature` works
- running `cucumber-js features/test/run.feature` fails because it doesn't find the step definitions 

Both `run.feature` files are identical.

title: An option to relax the arguments check for the step definitions
body:
Hi, Though I do understand the value of the strict checking that is being done for the step arguments, I also feel that there is need to pass this control back to the users. 

For example, in my case, I want to implement generic wrapper functions around the step implementation functions where I want to add some generic processing logic before and after the step invocation. For this generic wrapper, I need to access just whatever arguments were passed and hence need access to the arguments array rather than declaring any explicit parameters. Currently, cucumber would just stop me from doing this as it does a strict check of parameters. 

I would like to propose adding another configuration parameter to the options object called maybe something like skipStrictParameterCheck which if not set would be assumed as false. That way for most common usage the default behaviour would be strict checks but for others who want to use the framework to build something more around it, it gives them the flexibility to leverage some of the dynamic capabilities of JavaScript.

title: wait for the event queue to drain before starting the next step
body: In order to support asynchronous clean-up better, and increase overall robustness of the framework, it would be useful if CucumberJS would start the next scenario only after waiting for the event queue to drain. What this means is do a `setTimeout <continue>, 0` before running the next scenario. This gives any queued up asynchronous cleanup jobs from the previous scenario time to run before Cucumber starts with the next scenario.

title: Not calling the asynchronous callback on "BeforeFeatures" causes the test suite to be skipped silently
body:
Related to #487 

How to reproduce (code in LiveScript):

``` livescript
module.exports = ->

  @register-handler 'BeforeFeatures', (event, done) ->
    console.log 'BEFORE ALL'
```

Expected behavior:
- I see an error message telling me that I forgot to return from the "BeforeFeatures" hook.
- the test fails

Actual behavior: 
- it prints "BEFORE ALL"
- the test suite ends right there, no tests run
- the return code of the command is 0, indicating that the tests passed (which breaks CI servers)

title: "AfterFeatures" hook does not wait for the callback to be called
body:
Problematic code 

``` livescript
module.exports = ->

  @register-handler 'AfterFeatures', (event, done) ->
    console.log 'AFTER ALL'
```

Cucumber.js happily prints "AFTER ALL" and then exits right away. Ignoring such errors is not really user friendly, but encourages code that doesn't do what the developer thinks it does. Cucumber.js has a ton of asynchronous callbacks like those, I recommend using a systematic approach to make them all robust against
- not being called
- being called multiple times
- being called after already being timed out

If you don't want to re-invent the wheel here, https://github.com/Originate/robust-callbacks is a minimally invasive and well tested solution for this, and now stable.

title: determine which features use a step definition
body:
Ultimately , Cucumber determines which step definitions are involved in a feature file/scenario/step in order to execute the steps. Is there a way to access this information?

The reason I ask is that I'd like to map the dependencies such that when a file is changed, I can trace back to the feature files that are impacted and run only those tests.

```
someFeature.feature 
  depends on someSpecs.js
    depends on someSrcFile.js
```

If someSrcFile.js is changed, I can pretty easily determine that someSpecs.js is impacted, but I'd like to know that someFeature.feature is impacted , so I can do a cucumber run on that feature. Of course, in many cases there would be multiple specs files and thus multiple feature files impacted... the above is just a basic scenario.

I'm guessing that somewhere in Cucumber, the tree information is known, but I don't know where to go looking or whether that knowledge is exposed via API.

I'd love it if I could have cucumber parse the whole set of feature files without running any tests, and then query it to say, "for this specs file (someSpecs.js), which feature files depend on it?

Under [Running Specific Features](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js#running-specific-features), I see that I can run a feature based on a scenario name. I guess what would be great is if there is an extension like

``` bash
# runs all features that depend on someSpecs.js
cucumber.js --specs someSpecs.js
```

but I'd also be perfectly content to make the determination of which features depend on someSpecs.js through the API... I don't necessarily need a CLI option, and in fact I think I'd rather be able to do this via the API so I can hang on to the information about the dependency(ies).

title: TypeError: Cannot define property:callSite, object is not extensible
body:
I ran into a problem using CucumberJS with Selenium. I tracked it down to an interaction between stack-chain and Google's Closure Library. The result is a misleading stack trace that masks the underlying error.

```
      TypeError: Cannot define property:callSite, object is not extensible.
          at Function.defineProperty (native)
          at Object.defineProperty.set (/home/rlm/ws/cucumberjs-and-selenium-error/node_modules/cucumber/node_modules/stack-chain/stack-chain.js:195:12)
          at Function.prepareStackTrace (/home/rlm/ws/cucumberjs-and-selenium-error/node_modules/cucumber/node_modules/stack-chain/stack-chain.js:141:20)
          at promise.Promise.goog.defineClass.resolve_ (/home/rlm/ws/cucumberjs-and-selenium-error/node_modules/selenium-webdriver/lib/goog/../webdriver/promise.js:1128:38)
```

For more details and an example that demonstrates the problem, see [rleemorlang/cucumberjs-and-selenium-error](https://github.com/rleemorlang/cucumberjs-and-selenium-error).

For a potential upstream solution and a bit of discussion, see AndreasMadsen/stack-chain/issues/9.

title: Question: Why are Given, Then, When aliases?
body:
Take an example:

```
Given my cat's name is "Frank"
When I change my cat's name to "James"
Then my cat's name is "James"
```

When I implement these steps, the step definition `this.Given(/^my cat's name is "([^"]+)"$/, ...` matches both the Given and Then cases above (because the regex matches both cases).

Why are the `Given` and `Then` steps not unique in category? Why is a `Given` step allowed to match a `Then` step? A `Then` should always verify some state, whereas `Given` ensures it is as described --- very different actions.

body:
This PR has 2 pieces:
1. Add rerun formatter so, at the end of test it will log the failed scenarios alone (this could be saved to a text file)
2. Run the failed scenarios by reading the text file which has the failed scenarios log

Run test using rerun formatter:
As of now cucumber does not support saving the logs to a file, till then its a way to simulate how to use it.

> node bin/cucumber.js features/cli.feature -f rerun > rerun.txt

Run failed scenarios by reading the text file:
When any argument passed starts with '@' then it will take it as input file and read the content before executing the scenarios

> node bin/cucumber.js @rerun.txt

body:
I have a Scenario Outline set up with values in the Examples table that have multiple (escaped) special characters included.  During execution the first one encountered is escaped as expected, and used successfully, so rows with only a single special character run correctly.

However, when there are multiple escaped characters the subsequent ones are not escaped as expected.

For example:
**Given** I am on a webpage with special characters in the page title
**Then** Escaped characters should be escaped and the page title should be <pageTitle>

Examples: 
| pageTitle                                                                               |
| Home \| This is the Home Page                                            |
| Accounts Page \| This is the Accounts Page \| John Smith  |

The first line will get passed into the step as:
Home | This is the Home Page

But the second line gets passed as:
Accounts Page | This is the Accounts Page \| John Smith

So asserts against that value fail unless you include the spurious escape character.

Hope that is clear, if not let me know and I will try to add further examples.

title: Bug with version above 0.4.4 - HIGH SEVERITY

milestone.title: 1.0 release
milestone.description: Cucumber.js has caught up with the important features of Cucumber-ruby.

body:
We are facing issue with cucumberJS version above @0.4.4. It does not execute the @After hook if more than one scenarios are executed and each one fails when `element` is not found by WebDriver. It also does not print the JSON to the console.

Steps to Reproduce:

```
Install Cucumber version above 0.4.4
1. Run Two Scenarios (makes sure each one fails due to No Element Found by WebDriver)
2. Scenario 1 closes the browser (executes the @After hook)
3. Scenario 2 does not close the browser (does not execute @After hook(
4. Does not print JSON to the console
These steps are true if cucumber runs more than one scenarios.
```

Repeat above steps with Cucumber@0.4.4 version and it just works fine.

We are not able to generate Cucumber Report (and see the failures for our E2E) at all with cucumber version above 0.4.4. We have been forced to downgrade the version. We will appreciate any fix on this.

Thank you team,
Kushang

title: Format chai.js exceptions so to display a better diff
body:
I'm using [chai.js](https://github.com/chaijs/chai) to make assertions. Unfortunately, when I compare arrays, I have a poor result because Cucumber doesn't format Chai exceptions like other test runners such as [mocha.js](https://github.com/mochajs/mocha/blob/58e94445beb722372589cbd2a0372bf741e7f0b7/lib/reporters/base.js#L193) or [wallaby.js](https://github.com/wallabyjs/public/issues/186#issuecomment-120564448).

For instance, when I compare two big arrays:

```
actual_content.should.deep.equal(expected_content);
```

I get:

```
  AssertionError: expected [ Array(2) ] to deeply equal [ Array(2) ]
    at Assertion.assertEqual (/my_project/node_modules/chai/lib/chai/core/assertions.js:464:19)
    at Assertion.ctx.(anonymous function) [as equal] (/my_project/node_modules/chai/lib/chai/utils/addMethod.js:40:25)
    ...
```

Mocha, in this case would produce something like:

```
  AssertionError: expected [ 1, 2 ] to equal [ 3, 4 ]
  + expected - actual

   [
  -  1
  -  2
  +  3
  +  4
   ]

  at Context.<anonymous> (client/test/test_misc.js:20:27)
```

To be honest, this is annoying for big arrays only, because otherwise Chai produce a better exception message; see issue https://github.com/chaijs/chai/issues/469.

    at Object.getFeatures (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/cucumber/lib/cucumber/runtime.js:37:35)
    at Object.start (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/cucumber/lib/cucumber/runtime.js:16:37)

    at Object.<anonymous> (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/cucumber/bin/cucumber.js:4:5)
```

**System**
Darwin 14.4.0 Darwin Kernel Version 14.4.0: Thu May 28 11:35:04 PDT 2015; root:xnu-2782.30.5~1/RELEASE_X86_64 x86_64

**Replicate**
Create an empty .feature file, run cucumber.js and it will throw this error.

**Quick fix**
Remove the empty .feature file or put some dummy lines in there.

**Suggestion**
A more graceful warning, ignoring the empty file(s) and continue.

normalize OS-specific path separators when performing assertions on cucumber output
body: this pull request fixes #353

title: End-to-end tests are failing on Windows
body:
End-to-end tests are failing on Windows because the output of the pretty formatter contains feature file paths and these paths contain OS-specific directory separators. Under Windows it's backslash while the expected output contains slashes (the default separator in Unix).

We could fix this in two ways, we could either fix the actual formatter code to output paths consistently under different operating systems or we can fix the assertion code to ignore the separators.

I think it's more feasible to rely on the OS setting and fix only the assertion code.
