title: Contribution readme is not applicable to Windows
body:
Hi,

I'm trying to contribute some code but I have some problems with following the steps written in the readme file about contributing.
When you run `npm test` it executes the following:

```
  jshint bundler.js bin lib spec && jasmine-node spec && bin/cucumber.js -f progress -i
```

The problem with this is that the command `bin/cucumber.js` will work only from Linux/Unix. As far as I know Windows doesn't support shebangs.

So I would make another option to run the tests under Windows with the "Windows-version" of the command:

```
  jshint bundler.js bin lib spec && jasmine-node spec && node bin/cucumber.js -f progress -i
```

...assuming that node.js executable is on PATH.

I also don't know that these end-to-end cucumber scenarios are supposed to be passing or not. Currently I have 18 failing scenarios when I run the tests with the "Windows-version" of the command. This is strange because I haven't modified anything yet.

Maybe this is due to the environment problem?
Are the scenarios passing under Linux?

title: Running a single scenario
body:
Hi,

Maybe there is already some solution for doing this properly. Here is my use case: currently I'm using cucumber-js for automated smoke tests/end-to-end tests. These scenarios are not fast, it takes some minutes to execute all of them in a small project. When I'm starting to develop a new feature, I'd like to write some (failing) Cucumber scenarios and during the development, I'd like to run only some of them to check my implementation. 
Currently I'm using tags to achieve this behavior: I have a tag like "@inProgress" and have a Grunt task to run my scenarios marked with inProgress. This is a bit cumbersome, since I have to mark every scenarios with this tag and after my implementation task is done, I have to revert my changes manually because I don't want to commit them to Git. 
I see that you already have some plan to implement suites, maybe that feature would resolve this problem? 

Before I saw the suites issue I was just thinking about that we can expose the names of the scenarios to be executed to the CLI and make the scenarios to be "discoverable" for other tools. So I can write my own Cucumber-js test runner, which could display my scenarios on a nice UI where I can select which tests do I want to execute and I can execute them.

title: enable dry-run option
Steps with no arguments will fail in v0.5.0
Multiple bindings for the same step
body:
When I write Gherkins I'd like to use different phrasing for Given and When steps.

Let's see an example to demonstrate this use case:

```
Given the document '1.pdf' has already been converted
When I convert the document '2.pdf'
```

Both steps use the same step definition, just the phrasing (the regex pattern) is different.
Currently CucumberJS doesn't support this out of the box: you have to extract your step definition as a function every time you want to write a step with an alternative phrasing.

I suggest a nicer solution which is easy to implement:

```
this.When([/^the document '(.*)' has already been converted$/,
            /^I convert the document '(.*)'$/], function (documentName, callback) {
          // ...
});
```

If you want to try it out, I've already implemented a feature in my [cucumber-sweetener](https://github.com/zs-zs/cucumber-sweetener) project. (It's just not documented yet.)

Reusing gherkin code with different step definitions
body:
As you can see if the gherkin code is abstract enough, you can reuse it by testing the same behavior from different aspects. 

gherkin for changing password

``` cucumber
Feature User
    Scenario change password
        Given I am a registered customer
        When I change the old password to the new password
        Then I can login with the new password
            But I cannot login with the old password any longer
```

step definitions on plain english

e2e tests with selenium for desktop browser

```
    I am a registered customer
        -> email = customer@example.com
        -> oldPassword = example
    I change the old password to the new password
        -> visit login page
        -> fill in credentials
        -> click on the login button
        -> must be redirected to profile page
        -> click on the change password link
        -> fill in old and new passwords to the form
        -> click on the change button
    I can login with the new password
        -> click on logout button if logged in
        -> visit login page
        -> fill in credentials
        -> click on the login button
        -> must be redirected to profile page
    I cannot login with the old password any longer
        -> click on logout button if logged in
        -> visit login page
        -> fill in credentials
        -> click on the login button
        -> must be redirected to the login page
        -> the login page must contain invalid email or password message
```

integration tests probably with mocked out database

```
    I am a registered customer
        -> email = customer@example.com
        -> oldPassword = example
    I change the old password to the new password
        -> newPassword = 12345
        -> UserRepository.findByEmail(email).changePassword(oldPassword, newPassword)
    I can login with the new password
        -> Security.authenticate(email, newPassword) -> must succeed
    I cannot login with the old password any longer
        -> Security.authenticate(email, newPassword) -> must fail
```

probably you can write other step definitions for mobile browser, for desktop client using websockets, for the data access layer if you have such a thing, etc...

Is this supported somehow by cucumber-js?

title: Reusing different backgrounds
body:
I am currently learning cucumber and I was checking some examples here: https://github.com/webjam/webjam/tree/master/features

Most of the scenarios contains

``` cucumber
Given I am not logged in
```

or

``` cucumber
Given I am logged in
```

so this is a clearly reusable part of the features.

According to the documentation it should be moved to a Background e.g. by https://github.com/webjam/webjam/blob/master/features/home.feature

``` cucumber
Feature: Viewing the home page

  In order to see all the cool stuff
  I should be able to visit the home page

  Background:
    Given I am not logged in

  Scenario: not logged in
    When I view the home page
    Then I see the page

  Scenario: viewing / on a mobile
    When I view the home page from an iphone
    Then I am redirected to the mobile page

  Scenario: viewing / on a mobile with redirect-to-mobile=no
    When I view the home page from an iphone specifying redirect-to-mobile=no
    Then I am not redirected to the mobile page
    And I see the page

  Scenario: viewing the mobile version with an upcoming event, a past event and a post
    Given there is an upcoming event
      And there is a past event
      And there is a post
    When I view the mobile version of the home page
    Then I see the page

  Scenario: viewing the mobile version without any events or posts
    When I view the mobile version of the home page
    Then I see the page
```

The problem that sometimes not every scenario have the same background in a feature. So some of them need a logged in state, while some of the need a not logged in state. Afaik. there is no support to reuse such code. Probably split into multiple features, but I thought it would be better to use groups:

``` cucumber
Feature: Viewing post pages

  In order to absorb Lachlan's deep insights into man and machine
  I should be able to visit pages and pages and pages of blog posts

  Group:
    Background:
      Given I am logged in

    Scenario: viewing a post when logged in
      When I view the post page
      Then I see the page

    Scenario: viewing a mobile post when logged in
      When I view the mobile post page
      Then I see the page

    Scenario: viewing a mobile post when not logged in
      When I view the mobile post page
      Then I see the page


  Group:
    Background:
      Given I am not logged in

    Scenario: viewing a post when not logged in
      When I view the post page
      Then I see the page
```

By some of the cases this hierarchical grouping won't work, so this is not a perfect solution. Tagging would be perfect, but I am unsure whether I should use it in this cases. Any opinion?

Another possible solution to match the "when not logged in" part from the scenario text using a helper that adds the `Given I am not logged in`. So the code would be such simple:

``` cucumber
Feature: Viewing post pages

  In order to absorb Lachlan's deep insights into man and machine
  I should be able to visit pages and pages and pages of blog posts

    Scenario: viewing a post when logged in
      When I view the post page
      Then I see the page

    Scenario: viewing a mobile post when logged in
      When I view the mobile post page
      Then I see the page

    Scenario: viewing a mobile post when not logged in
      When I view the mobile post page
      Then I see the page

    Scenario: viewing a post when not logged in
      When I view the post page
      Then I see the page
```

I am not sure whether this is possible by the current test runner.

title: Make cucumber support a separate project
body:
Cucumber support has been sketchy and community-driven for a while. See the disclaimer at http://angular.github.io/protractor/#/frameworks#using-cucumber

Now that a custom framework can be used, we should just make it a separate project to clarify this separation, and unblock protractor releases when weird things are going on with cucumber.

title: Make pretty the default formatter on CLI
body: @aslakhellesoy thanks for raising this.

title: scenario.attach(string) not working
Need a way to access chai's "should" object
body:
[Edited to reflect that the problem occurs in a meteor velocity testing context.]

When using cucumber-js within meteor velocity, chai.should() is automatically called but there is currently no way to access the object that it returns. That object is normally used like this:

```
should = chai.should(); 
should.exist(var_which_could_be_undefined);
```

One solution would be to make the object returned by chai.should() available as global.should.

title: Please document datatable interface

milestone.title: 1.0 release
milestone.description: Cucumber.js has caught up with the important features of Cucumber-ruby.

title: runtime.jst configuration.isStrictRequested() should not be called if it not exists
body:
The `configuration.isStrictRequested()` call should only be made if this function exists. Otherwise, the catch handler is called but the exception is still reported as first-chance in the Visual Studio IDE interrupts the program flow.

Simple fix:

```
isStrictRequested    = configuration.isStrictRequested && configuration.isStrictRequested();
```

title: Making DOMFormatter ready for Windows App
body: The current `DOMFormatter` relies on JQuery and uses `innerHTML` which is prohibited in Windows Store apps. There is a replacement for `innerHTML` though. I'd like to create a patched version of `DOMFormatter` yet I fail to find it in the source? Its contained in `release/cucumber.js`.

title: Add failure exception to scenario object
body: As @jlin412 suggested in #250 it would be nice to have access to thrown exception in scenario object.

title: Suites
body: See https://github.com/Behat/Behat/blob/master/features/suite.feature and https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/issues/821

title: Removes color when no tty exists and cli params are included

milestone.title: 1.0 release
milestone.description: Cucumber.js has caught up with the important features of Cucumber-ruby.

body:
Previous when cucumber was piped / used in a tty-less environment the
colour codes ended up being printed, this makes the output unreadable,
mostly the "pretty" formatter.

This does some auto detection based on tty and terminal capabilities and
disables colors when they are unable to be printed.

Also included are cli parameters which can be used to force the colors
on / off.

These are:

``` sh
--no-color
--color=false
--color=true
--color=always
--color
```

title: Accessing the step object.
body:
I was wondering if there is any way to access the test step object from the step implementation or a hook. I'm referring to the object defined [here](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/master/lib/cucumber/ast/step.js).

The reason I'm trying to access the step is for logging purposes. I have a couple of common test steps which log what they're doing, which is a terrific help when writing testcases. To structure this log I want each step to log it's line ('Executing step: Given some condition is true'), so I would like to access the steps `.getLine()` method.

I assumed I could use the `beforeStep()` hook for this, similar how you can use `beforeScenario()` to get the scenario object. However, although it gives back a step object as its first argument, it is the step object of the hook itself.

I read in other issues that there is a bit of controversy around the `beforeStep()` hook, but I don't really see any alternatives in this case.

title: support for profiles

fixes #299

title: Add .hash method to DataTable objects
body:
Currently, they expose `.rows()` and `.hashes()`, but both of these return an array. If I'm using a data table to represent a key-value mapping, like

```
Feature: Tables as objects
    Scenario: I want to represent myself as a table
        Given I have the following properties
            | color | light pink  |
            | size  | fat         |
            | age   | 24          |
            | name  | mark        |
            | job   | code monkey |
        Then I should be able to get myself in my step definition as an object mapping properties to values
```

then neither of these is convenient.

The Java API for Cucumber seems to support this - see 'Map of Scalar' at https://cukes.info/step-definitions.html#map_of_scalar. Can the JS version support it too, perhaps as a `.hash()` method?

As an aside, I'd've been able to add this from userland if `Cucumber.Ast.DataTable` were implemented as a proper constructor that were invoked with `new`, rather than just a function that creates an object and returns it. I'm not sure if the decision to implement things the way they are is a carefully considered style decision to deliberately prevent prototype changes being made from userland, or if this just wasn't thought about?

title: A new feature for switching environment of data table.
body:
We used cucumber to test our websites and met a problem about the data table of scenario outline features. Data table will test all data rows which we defined, but we need to skip some data rows when these testing are running in different environment, such as alpha, beta, production. Here is the example of new feature. 
     Feature: testing scenarios
        Scenario Outline: scenario outline 1
          When step 

        Examples:
          |_env   | id |
          | alpha | a  |
          | beta  | b  |
          | all   | c  |
If you executed command cucumber.js append with "-data_env beta", then cucumber will only execute two data rows, both of them are "beta" and "all". 
jasmine-node spec && ./bin/cucumber.js -i features/xx.feature  -data_env beta

title: Possible race condition in step_definition.js?
body:
Starting from version 0.4.6 Cucumber started to occasionally abort with exit code 0, especially when stepdefs or custom formatters use promises. I am actually struggling to create an isolated reproducible scenario that would not involve third-party components. Here is an example: https://gist.github.com/nebehr/ffd002ba937943803859. It requires protractor and q as dependencies. When "protractor conf.js" is executed, in Cucumber 0.4.6 browser window remains opened when the execution is complete. In Cucumber 0.4.5 it closes as it should. This demo is a bit indirect but it should serve the purpose (and I am absolutely sure that the issue is not in Protractor, it's just there to demonstrate the problem).

I may be wrong, but it seems that the problem occurs in stepDomain.dispose() in step_definition.js:54, after domain.exit() was called from exception.js:16. Looks like everything works  only when there are no delayed or time-consuming promises in the code. Maybe stepDomain.dispose() has become redundant with the changes in exception.js? Unfortunately I do not know enough about Node domains to be able to supply a PR for this.

title: Speculative: using tags to select step definition sources
body:
Hi.
This Pull Request is to see if this feature is acceptable for the main project before I start refining it and cleaning up the tests.
## Purpose

This is designed to make the file system layout and arrangement of features
more flexible. Target audience is larger projects with multiple
developers.

Changes:
- Throws errors if more than one step definition matches a feature step.
- Small fixes for file path matching in Windows.
- **Special tag format for selecting which files are used for steps.**

The special tags are designed to be used where the `-r` tag is specified.
They should work where file name matching is done, but will be less
useful.
## Tags

If no source tags are set, default behaviour is used: all matching step
definitions will be used to fulfil a step.

If one or more file source tags are set in a file, then only the
specified sources are used. Sources accumulate, so each tag ADDS to the
available pool of definitions.

Tags are inherited, so setting at a feature level sets for all
scenarios.

Specific named file tags don't use path or `.js` ending. Files with the
matching name will be allowed as step definitions:

```
@:MySteps
```

Will match (e.g.)

```
./step_definitions/MySteps.js
./step_definitions/specific/path/MySteps.js
```

Directory path tags match against the end of the step files' path.
This is non-recursive, so child directories will not be used.

```
@./Interpretation
```

Will match

```
./step_definition/Interpretation/x.js
./step_definition/Interpretation/y.js
```

 ./step_definition/deeper/Interpretation/x.js

But not

```
./step_definition/Interpretation/deeper/y.js
```

Any steps loaded from {step path}/support/ will be included
regardless of tags
## Example feature file using the tags

``` cucumber
@./DataAccess
Feature: we need a local data store that persists incoming catalog data.
  We should be able to query the most recent data stored.
  We should be able to delete the entire data store ready for a refresh
  Data should not be modifiable once written.

  Scenario: storing data
    Given a running database instance
    And a DAL connected to it
    When I call to the DAL to store object data for an entity
    Then the call should complete with no errors

  @:DeleteEnabled_steps
  Scenario: deleting data
    Given a running database instance
    And a DAL connected to it
    When I call to the DAL to delete all data
    Then the call should complete with no errors
```

title: Asynchronous Tests Don't Complete Properly
body:
I've been using Cucumber to write integration tests for a client/server messaging framework. 

My Then step included waiting for a response from the server: 

```
this.Then /^the "([^"]*)" eventually receives a message with a payload of "([^"]*)"$/, (name, payload, callback) ->
    serviceState = this[name]
    serviceState.wasCalledPromise.then(callback, callback.fail)
```

I was expecting the fake latency to eventually resolve a promise on the client side, at which point I would callback success / failure. I was happily coding away to green test suites until I realised that this final step wasn't being outputted on the console - the previous steps were all successful but this step didn't exist.

I had a defect in my code where the client wasn't actually subscribing to the server properly. I was expecting this to appear as a "pending" case, or something like that. But without a setTimeout keeping the test alive it just passes on / terminates without acknowledging the lack of a callback to this step.

I wouldn't expect a step that started executing, but never finished, to not appear in the output.

title: Remove "npm install --dev" suggestion from Readme
body:
So I was trying to install cucumberjs. Not wanting to install it globally first I though to use the

```
npm install --dev
```

way as defined in the README.md (including defining cucumber as devDependency). After 2 hours of downloading 1.7 GB (!) and heavy cpu usage (in this order) the installation quit with:

```
Segmentation fault: 11
```

I strongly discourage installing cucumber this way. I suppose that --dev installs all the dev dependencies which is A LOT:

```
# find . -name node_modules -type d -exec ls {} \; | uniq | wc -l
22352
```

Installation via

```
npm install -g cucumber
```

took seconds.

I'm not sure if I'm the only one experiencing this, but if not, I would suggest removing this installation suggestion from the readme.

title: Fix issue with npm upgrade on node.js v0.8
body: This fixes #254.  The fix is based on the information in two comments at https://github.com/npm/npm/issues/6246 and also an approach to implementing conditional Travis CI before_install steps described at https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-ci/issues/1785#issuecomment-31253761 (using the fix to logic in replacing the `=` with a `!=` and the `&&` with a `||` desribed at the bottom of the comment https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-ci/issues/1785#issuecomment-31253761).

title: Fix issue with non-ASCII characters in Buffer and Stream attachments
body:
This fixes #249.  Buffers are not converted to strings using `buffer.toString('binary')` instead of `buffer.toString()`.  `buffer.toString()` defaults to `utf8` which broken any non-ASCII characters.  

This pull request also includes a fix for an issue in features/attachments.feature that meant the node.js version wasn't detected correctly and meant that streams weren't being tested in the feature file (they were still being tested in the specs).

title: Use nodejs domain error handler instead of uncaughtError handle
body:
Refer https://github.com/angular/protractor/issues/876#issuecomment-57892972. 
Prefer using the domain error handler instead of the top level Cucumber uses the top level uncaught error handler to catch exceptions
caught by tests.  Refer commit
https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/commit/9091129df4866cf705fb4ea7fb488f81e7cb96c2
and issue #51.  A good approach would be to wrap the test code
executions in try/catch blocks and use that exception instead of the
`uncaughtException` handler.  Another approach is to use the error
handler of a nodejs domain instead of the top level global
uncaughtException handler.  In this commit, I'm using the domain level
error handler approach.

title: Fix for #251
body:
Fix for #251 
- on windows paths need to be normalized - gherkin lexer files were not found
- disabled 'debug' mode of browserify - it was creating huge source map and size of bundled file was exceding > 2MB
- added optional param to the bundle script:
  $ node scripts/release.js gherkinLang=XX 
  i.e:
  $ node scripts/release.js gherkinLang=en
  By default it includes all languages

title: scenario does not have an exception property like ruby version
Cannot attach non string data to report
body: I think because of the fix for [#233](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/233) the scenario.attach now only supports string data. If you try to pass it any other type it will have toString() called on it (previously toString('base64')) and if you try to pass data which is already base64 encoded then it gets it gets based64 encoded again at the formatting stage in the json formatter. @simondean mentioning you as instructed.

title: Support i18n in snippet generation
jshintrc added
body:

title: Cucumber.js v0.4.3 sometimes skips scenario outlines.
body:
We noticed that in v0.4.3 certain scenario outlines are skipped. They are not marked as failing or pending steps, but simply excluded from the test output (checked with both the json and pretty formatter), giving the impression that all tests ran succesfully when, in fact, some were skipped.

I have  built a small test-case to demonstrate the bug, which can be found [here](https://gist.github.com/jwoudenberg/19ed03a71d6015388112). Please check and run the scenario. `Scenario two` is recognized, but the step in it is not. Weirdly, removing an additional line from the example table of the `Scenario one` makes `Scenario two` run properly.

title: World is not context for event listeners
Allow > 2 parameters in string step definitions
body:
The current implementation does not do a global reg ex replace for string step definitions.. This means the maximum number of placeholders could be 1 quoted dollar placeholder and 1 dollar placeholder. You couldn't have 2 dollar placeholders. 

For example the following would happen..

```
'I have "$btnA" and "$btnB" buttons
-> ^I have "([^"]*)" and "(.*)"$ (still works by coincidence)
```

And...

```
'I have $countA accounts and $countB projects' 
-> ^I have (.*) accounts and $countB projects$ 
```

title: Runner invokes support files that export a function
body:
This looks like it's deliberate, and I suspect most of the time it'd be useful, but if you have a support file that exports only a function (in my case a constructor) the [support_code_loader](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/master/lib/cucumber/cli/support_code_loader.js#L59) will invoke it.

This causes serious issues in my case, where I'm not expecting my constructor to be invoked in the context of the `support_code_loader`. It's not the behaviour I expected so I thought I'd bring it up so it gets some exposure.

title: stepResult event triggered for hooks in 0.4.2
Scenario outline fixes
body:
This pull request fixes the following issues:
- #177 Empty Scenario Outline still calls Before and After hooks
- #180 Execution order of scenarios and scenario outlines in a feature
- #185 Before/After hooks on Scenario Outline called incorrectly
- #217 Scenario Outlines with multiple Examples sections only executing the very last Examples
- #224 Issue with tables in feature in version 0.4.2

@jbpros this pull request changes the behaviour of Scenario Outlines.  Scenario outlines are no longer present in the AST once the parsing has finished.  I.e. the scenario outlines are removed from the AST features when they are converted into scenarios.  The other way to have solved, these issues would have been something like changing the AstTreeWalker to not visit scenario outlines.  Which way to fix it do you think is best?  It would be good to know whether the Ruby and JVM ports of cucumber include the scenario outlines in the AST.  One thing that makes me wonder is that cucumber-jvm already includes the backgrounds in the AST.  

Because the scenario outlines are no longer in the AST, you no longer see them reported by the formatters/listenders.

title: Fix test script to be more portable
Add timestamp to JSON formatter output
body:
We're recording Selenium based tests and use this to compute time offsets to skip around in our screen recordings.

Currently there is no easy method to get an _absolute_ time from Cucumber output. The only approach is to see when Cucumber starts/terminates and subtract `duration` properties from that time. This is skewed by various other things (for example browser starting up before the first step gets executed).

Summing up `duration` is quite a hassle, and can be easily circumvented by this patch. This is just a hack, and does not pass tests. Please help me finding the correct way to implement such a timestamp.

title: Internet Explorer compatibility fix and bugfix
body:
- IE9-10 require explicit contexts to be passed to function pointers in certain cases (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/gg622930%28v=vs.85%29.aspx). The `process.nextTick` implementation used for IE, which is based on `setImmediate`, was updated to accept and pass an explicit context to the callback.
- The implementation for DataTable.Row did not declare `self` to be a local variable, and IE9 wouldn't allow a new value to be assigned to it.

title: Adding short stack traces as an option
body:
Updated the package to include a command line option that allows the user to specify whether or not they would like single line stack traces upon step failure.

Currently the stack traces that are output by the package in the event of a step failure are pretty large and make it a little more difficult to see what has failed. The changes I have made cut this trace down to a single line and shows only the line in the code that caused the step to fail.

The changes involved slight modifications to runtime, configuration, argument parser and step_definition.

I believe this addition would benefit others as it seems this issue has been flagged already.

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/157

title: Support code loader now works with windows
body:
Hi,
   I found an issue when running cucumberjs under windows.  It was not loading the support files before the step definitions.  This was because the regexp in the support_code_loader.js file was hard coded to a 'normal' file path.  Obviously, windows has to be different as always, so I have added a test for the windows platform and used backslashes in the regexp when this test passes.
I have since ran the unit tests which all pass

I could not think of a way to test this change in the unit test as I needed to spy on 'os.platform()' and return different values.  This would have needed to have been done before the code was loaded.

I have also tested it using my test suite (which contains a good 200+ steps) and it works on both linux (which it always did) and windows (which didn't work previously).

This pull request as you can see contains the required change.

Hopefully you can include this in the next release and I can remove my fork from github.

Thanks

Gary

title: Cucumber tests for cucumber-js include a number of undefined steps
body:
Hi.  cucumber-js uses Ruby Cucumber and cucumber-js to test itself.  The output from these two test runs include a number of undefined scenarios.  It's not possible to know if these undefined scenarios are masking regressions.  It would be good to use the --strict option with Ruby cucumber and cucumber-js when cucumber-js tests itself.  

Ruby Cucumber is executed from the Rakefile

``` ruby
  desc "Run the features through Cucumber (Ruby) and Aruba"
  task :rb do
    sh %{ cucumber -p quiet }
  end
```

cucumber-js is executed from the package.json

``` json
  "scripts": {
    "test": "./bin/cucumber.js && jasmine-node spec"
  },
```

title: Scenario Outlines with multiple Examples sections only executing the very last Examples
body:
Given the following feature file 

``` gherkin
      Feature: testing scenarios with multiple examples section
        Scenario Outline: outline
          When a table step:
            | first   | second   |
            | <first> | <second> |

        Examples: First set of examples
          | first   | second  |
          | 1       | 2       |

        Examples: Second set of examples
          | first   | second  |
          | 3       | 4       |
          | 5       | 6       |
```

when it's run with cucumber.js 0.4.1, it reports running only two tests (after inspection it's clear it has only run the "Second set of examples")

```
..

2 scenarios (2 passed)
2 steps (2 passed)
```

However, when running the same feature file  with the python [behave](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/behave/1.2.4) tool, it runs all examples - 3 scenarios

```
[...]
1 feature passed, 0 failed, 0 skipped
3 scenarios passed, 0 failed, 0 skipped
3 steps passed, 0 failed, 0 skipped, 0 undefined
```

I don't _know_ which one is the correct behavior. To me the behave version feels correct. But I haven't worked with the ruby based cucumber, so it might be the case that behave is wrong

Due to my lack of ruby experience, I wasn't able to verify this by adding this scenario to the [relevant feature file](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/master/features/scenario_outlines.feature#L31) and run it locally. But I expect that adding the above example to it is straightforward

title: --no-snippets flag for CLI

Now you are able to pass `--no-snippets` to the CLI and the formatters will not output the step definition snippets. So I added a `snippets` key to the `options` of the CLI configuration and set the value to `true` by default. This `options` object gets passed down to the summary formatter that supress the output of the snippets. I refactored the existing tests and added new specs and tests.

body:
Right now it is possible to call callback fn multiple times in a step definition - this results with abnormal behavior - following/next steps are triggered for every callback invocation - this is simple check to prevent this + print to output that callback was called multiple times for some step.

I think that it improvement is useful during test development because async code based on events may trigger callback fn multiple times - it is not always obvious what is happening.

title: Configurable step timeout
body:
Based on the discussion in https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/27 i would like to propose this solution :
1) every time step is called ( invoked ) set a timeout with predefined value ( 30s ) , if callback in this step is not called ( success,fail or pending ) call callback.fail() with "Timeout" message - so it is invoked in the scope of the test - this way it has access to all details

2) Regarding configuration - there are two ways :
a) using CLI - add -t ( --timeout ) option with value in ms
b) when constructing new runner ( var runner = Cucumber(featureSource, supportCodeInitializer, options) ) - pass additional 'timeout' option with value in ms
Default value set to 30s is a save bet - in most cases nothing should take more then 30s - but since it is configurable it can be adjusted to the environment  

I believe that the same solution may be applied for hooks. 
I'm not particularly happy with configuration - please review it, i think that there may be better way to access Cucumber.Runtime.stepTimeoutValue...

Being able to define a timeout and get a feedback from the runner that some step has never finished is critical in my opinion - right now i developer may get false-positive results from the tests and it is harder to debug the tests and application code.

Please let me know if is valid solution in your opinion

``` shell
npm ERR! cwd /home/travis/build/cucumber/cucumber-js
npm ERR! node -v v0.8.26
npm ERR! npm -v 1.2.30
```

It looks like bower dropped support for node.js v0.8 a couple of months ago: https://github.com/bower/bower/commit/cea53ddd1f17ee741f86f1ae4d3cc5e8c80fd7e2

cucumber-js uses an older version of Bower but I wonder if some of Bower's dependencies no longer support node.js v0.8/v0.6.  

Removing bower as a dev dependency makes the build go green.  I think Bower isn't normally needed for development of cucumber-js.  I think it was only needed the first time cucumber-js was registered with the Bower registry (http://bower.io/#registering-packages) which is a one off activity.  Would you be happy with removing Bower as a dependency?

title: Non-English lexers not available in release package
body:
In the [release package](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/master/release/cucumber.js) there is only English lexer included. This means that when using cucumber-js in browser environment i18n doesn't work.

I'm interested in running cucumber-js with karma (via [karma-cucumberjs](https://github.com/s9tpepper/karma-cucumberjs) adapter). That's why I need a browser-friendly package.

title: Before/After hooks on Scenario Outline called incorrectly
body:
When implementing a very simple Scenario Outline, it appears that the Before/After hooks are called in succession before the first Scenario is ran. For a simple Scenario Outline with two examples, the traced output is:

_Actual:_
Before
After
Before
 -Given
. -When
. -Then
.After
Before
 -Given
. -When
. -Then
.After

_Expected:_
Before
 -Given
. -When
. -Then
.After
Before
 -Given
. -When
. -Then
.After

title: Please make 'features' accessible through BeforeFeatures/AfterFeatures events

This would give more freedom to the third-party extensions (which (just an example) may need to know total number of steps before scenarios start to execute) as well make events more consistent in respect to data access (*Features seem to be the only events lacking payload).

title: Would you consider adding --grep & --invert CLI options?
body:
I'm curious whether you would consider introducing these options to filter out unneeded scenarios (just like [Mocha](http://visionmedia.github.io/mocha/) does)? It would probably come handy while debugging some failing scenario(s) (without the need to introduce temporary tags, etc).

It seems to be very easy to implement (so that we don't have to [monkey patch](https://gist.github.com/shyiko/6ca40d0733afa09f7699) the poor thing) and I'll be happy to send a pull request (in case you think it's a good idea). 

Thank you.

title: visitRow function is unused

title: Execution order of scenarios and scenario outlines in a feature
body:
In features, scenarios should be executed in order, top to bottom, no matter if they are scenarios or scenario outlines.

```
Feature: Scenario order

    Scenario: 1
        Given Foo

    Scenario Outline: 2
        Given Foo
    Examples:
        | foo |
        | 1   |

    Scenario: 3
        Given Foo

    Scenario Outline: 4
        Given Foo
    Examples:
        | Bar |
        | 1   |

    Scenario: 5
        Given Foo
```

This should be executed in 1,2,3,4,5 order but it is executed 1,3,5,2,4.

title: Implement an option for the pretty formatter hide source uris
body:
A recent change in cucumber.js has caused the pretty formatter to always output a source uri before every feature and step:

Feature: some feature
        Scenario: I haven't done anything yet   # features\a.feature:2
          Given I have not defined this step    # features\a.feature:3

This caused our CI server to output a lot more text than necessary (the path names are very long).

This pull request allows you to change whether or not these source uris are printed out using the `--no-source` command line flag.

The pull request also includes cucumber tests for this new functionality under features/pretty_formatter.feature

title: Documentation and test for AfterFeatures event
body:
I spent ages doing the wrong setup for AfterFeatures to try and close my browser at the end of the tests, so I thought that including a test and better documentation might help other people.

This also fixes the unimplemented cli.feature step, and failing assert due to console coloring.

I had to apply the [patch from comments](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/120#issuecomment-22955066) in #120 to get these tests to run correctly.

title: Adding an event listener to AfterFeatures causes process to always exit with code 0
body:
```
Scenario: run cucumbers on a CI server
    As a developer using a CI server, I want to run my tests from a shell task 
    and know whether they have passed or failed from the exit code of the 
    shell command.
    I also want to be able to close my automated browser after all the features 
    have run.

    When I add an AfterFeatures callback to hooks.js
     And I run a failing test
    Then I expect to see the process exit with code "1" 
    #this fails with code "0"
```

This causes our CI server to think that the tests have passed when they have not.

The following commit adds a cucumber test to the project to demonstrate this behaviour:
f89bc268a22838fd17a8a998df8ea6200710cd73

title: Add command line argument handling for running single scenarios in features
body:
Like other cucumber implementations, it would be nice to be able to run just a single scenario in a large feature file using the command line argument pattern featurefilename.feature:linenum.

This involved making sure any "expandPaths" calls could ignore, yet preserve, the line number suffix, so that once the feature file source is loaded, the parser has access to the scenario.getUri() with the specified line number (if any). Then an astFilter can simply include or exclude scenarios if a line number was passed.

I had to fix one unimplemented (mislabelled) step in cli_steps.js and also apply the patch in issue #120 / #123 because the stdout not being fully flushed causes the cli.features to fail.

Look forward to any feedback.

Cheers
Simon

title: bump coffee-script
body:
Version 1.7.x of CoffeeScript requires that you register it before requiring .coffee files in node.

```
When requiring CoffeeScript files in Node you must now explicitly register the compiler. This can be done with require 'coffee-script/register' or CoffeeScript.register(). Also for configuration such as Mocha's, use coffee-script/register.
```

So, I have added the register method to the initialize method of support code loading and the error described in #153 goes away.

title: Support for partitioning a test suite (to aid in parallelized test runs)
body:
Given a big body of features and scenarios, it's nice to be able to partition the list of tests and run those pieces in parallel. One straightforward way to achieve this is: if there are `N` test runners, then the `i`-th runner only runs test scenario `j` if `(j % N) == i`.

This pull request is an implementation of a filter using the modular arithmetic logic described above. This is analogous to the tag filter which determines which scenarios to run based on tags passed at the command line. To invoke a segmented run of the tests, one runs:

`cucumber.js --parts 3 --remainder 0` in runner 0
`cucumber.js --parts 3 --remainder 1` in runner 1
`cucumber.js --parts 3 --remainder 2` in runner 2

This seemed rare enough to not really matter, but worth mentioning anyway.

title: "When" and "then" bug
body:
When I have a scenario containing a gherk that repeats itself in a "when" and a "then", we get two methods in the step definitions. When implementing the gherks, cucumber uses only the "when" implementation and ignores the "then" implementation. Both implementations are identical (but they can differ in, for example, in a console.log command). 
Scenario: do something
   Given...
   When i click log out 
   and I am redirected to login page
   And I visit gmail
   Then I am redirected to login page

Cucumber ignores "then" implementation. 
Even though both implementations are identical (and we ignore the small unnecessary difference) do we really need two stubs or is this redundant? Should this be fixed? How would we combine these stubs to apply for both without confusion?

title: success and failed properties in after and around hooks
Dry Run
body:
Hi.  The Ruby port of cucumber includes a --dry-run option.  It's really useful for discovering the scenarios in a codebase without having to execute them.  Here's the description of --dry-run from running `cucumber --help`: 

``` shell
    -d, --dry-run          Invokes formatters without executing the steps.
                           This also omits the loading of your support/env.rb file if it exists.
```

title: JSON Formatter only escapes first space character in feature Id
body:
Hi.  There's a bug in the JSON formatter in the way that spaces are escaped in the feature ID.  Only the first space in a feature name is escaped with a hyphen.  

``` javascript
[{
    "id": "Waiting-10 seconds",
    "name": "Waiting 10 seconds",
    "description": "",
    "line": 1,
    "keyword": "Feature",
    "uri": "C:\\code\\myriad\\myriad-cucumber-js-example\\features\\waiting\\waiting_10_seconds.feature",
    "elements": [{
        "name": "Waiting 10 seconds",
        "id": "Waiting-10 seconds;waiting-10-seconds",
        "line": 4,
        "keyword": "Scenario",
        "description": "",
        "type": "scenario",
        "tags": [{
            "name": "@api",
            "line": 3
        }]
    }]
}]
```

The bug is in this line of `lib/cucumber/listener/json_formatter.js`: 

``` javascript
currentFeatureId = feature.getName().replace(' ', '-'); // FIXME: wrong abstraction level, this should be encapsulated
```

Using a regex in the replace would fix it.  

``` javascript
currentFeatureId = feature.getName().replace(/ /g, '-'); // FIXME: wrong abstraction level, this should be encapsulated
```

Do the other ports of cucumber just escape spaces or other characters too?

title: Possible typos in README.md
body:
Could be confusing for non-english speakers, or those unfamiliar with regexes.

If not useful, please do close.

Thanks :)

title: Add step duration to the JSON Formatter
body:
Hi.  The JSON reports generated by the Ruby version of Cucumber include a duration value for each step in a scenario, with the duration being the amount of time it took for the step to execute.  This is really useful for using Cucumber for system health testing as you can trend and set thresholds for both the duration of each step and the duration of the scenario (buy summing the duration of all the steps in the scenario).  

Here's the Ruby Cucumber test for this feature: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/features/docs/formatters/json_formatter.feature (search the file for "duration": 1)

The feature was introduced in version 1.2.2 of Cucumber (see https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/History.md)

Here's the issue / pull request that is credited with introducing the feature: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/pull/329

title: Embedding screenshots in JSON and HTML reports
body:
Hi. The Ruby version of cucucmber includes a really useful feature for embedding files in its JSON and HTML reports.  This is especially useful for including browser screenshots in the report (e.g. screenshots taken with Selenium WebDriver when a scenario fails) .  

Here's the page on cukes.info that describes the feature: http://cukes.info/reports.html#embedding_screenshots

Here's the test for the feature in Ruby cucumber: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/fixtures/json/features/embed.feature

(If it helps) I think this is the test for it in cucumber-jvm: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/blob/master/core/src/test/java/cucumber/runtime/ScenarioResultTest.java

Thanks
Simon

Loading gherkin parser according language comment
body:
Hello there.

This issue could be seen as a duplicate of #109 but @vslinko stopped working on this - I'm willing to give it a try.

I've been working on the same problems @vslinko faced in issue #109 : a lexing error when parsing the first non-comment line (exactly, when parsing the first keyword).
Tests and specs run ok this time - but I've stumbled on the same problems with the non-en parsers.

When debugging this issue, it seemed that valid data was passed to the non-en parser. I'm wondering if it's a parser issue or an encoding issue on our part.

Could you give me directions:
- how could I dig deeper into this?
- how could I create a sample testcase to check if this problem is on gherkin's/cucumber-js's side?
- should I request support on the mailing list?

Some details about this PR:
- works only if the "# language" meta is on the first line
- does a "featureSource.toString", which is not optimal for nodejs implementation (since we're converting the buffer to a plain string)
- this code should be modified in the future if we want to support other meta comments like "# encoding"

title: Number extractions are actually stings
body:
Because I'm using CoffeeScript in my current project all comparisons are strict. For example:

``` coffeescript
someNumber = 2
someNumber is '2' #=> false
someNumber == '2' #=> false
```

This caught me out when writing a step definition:

``` coffeescript
@Then /^I should receive a (\d+) response code$/, (statusCode, callback)->
  if @response.statusCode is statusCode
    callback()
  else
    callback.fail "Unexpected response status code #{@response.statusCode}. Was excpeting #{statusCode}."
```

Because the `@response.stausCode` property is an integer, the above will always fail as the `statusCode` variable is actually a string. Every time I wish to use a number extraction within a step definition I usually end up parsing it first for good measure:

``` coffeescript
@Then /^I should receive a (\d+) response code$/, (statusCode, callback)->
  statusCode = parseInt statusCode
  ...
```

Do you think it would be a good idea to extract digits as actual integers?

title: CoffeeScript step definition snippets
body:
Here's a way to get the step definition snippets in CoffeeScript syntax (raised in [issue #65](https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/issues/65)). I really wanted to use them, so thought I'd go ahead and try to patch.

I've removed the static properties from `Cucumber.SupportCode.StepDefinitionSnippetBuilder` and created new syntax behaviors `Cucumber.SupportCode.StepDefinitionSnippetBuilderSyntax.JavaScript` and `Cucumber.SupportCode.StepDefinitionSnippetBuilderSyntax.CoffeeScript` which will switch dependent on the `--coffee` CLI option.

To be honest, it's the first time I've used Jasmine properly, so you may think that what I've done could be improved.

Ta,
John

title: timeouts
body: forgetting to call the callback function or an error in the SUT will have cucumber.js running forever. therefore, tests should time out after a configurable amount of time.

title: Add 'around all features' hook
body:
Hi,

It would be great if there was a hook available that could execute code before and after all the features have been run.

I am currently using WebDriver to automate browser testing. In order to speed things up, I am reusing a single browser instance that is available to each scenario. I therefore need to initialize the browser instance before the features are about to be run, and then close it down after they have finished.

I can't seem to find an elegant way to achieve this functionality at the moment. I have ended up invoking the CLI class directly from a custom Node app, and inserting my WebDriver init/shutdown code there.

Cheers
Pete

title: Use requirejs style for loading modules.
body:
- Remove underscore dependency by adding array utilities.
  Necessary to unhinge the library from a node-specific
  environment. Added a an array utility function to replace it
  with tests.
- Make requirejs modules callable from Node.
  By using amddefine node module.
- Add usage information for -format option. In preparation
  to add more formatters.
- Make example code run against requirejs-using Cucumber now.
- Remove browserify dependency. This was something else that
  tightly bound the library to Node.

Of note:

Had to fix circular requirejs dependencies that broke cucumber in the browser in my previous pull request. Now everything looks like it's ok. Cucumber/Jasmime tests all pass. Tested the example server page. Tested in phantomjs with dojo toolkit.

Unfortunately, the way that jasmine requires a scope object to spy on a method, prevents you from requiring a dependency directly in the requirejs scope. So you have to require a level above you so that the tests can pass. But this gets you into a circular dependency situation. Thankfully, requirejs allows for a way to resolve this at module runtime by providing a synchronous version of require() after all modules have loaded.

Removing dependency on Browserify and underscore was necessary. The problem was that it tied cucumber-js to Node. You had to run a Node server. While making it possible to run in a browser, in order to do that Browserify defines it's own set of require/define functions a'la Node (strict CommonJS) in the browser. This makes it awkward to use cucumber with other JavaScript toolkits that already have their set of AMD require/define functions. For example, require.js is one package that defines the AMD functions. Dojo is another that defines the AMD functions (based largely on require.js and 100% compatible). jQuery is also compatible with AMD and requirejs. With this, now you can take cucumber-js and run it in any server with any number of javascript toolkits that support AMD.

title: Couldn't connect to database from cucumber world script
body:
I try to connect to my mongodb database from cucumber's world script,
I tried two mongo adapters, and both they're failed, but executing same code
from plain node.js console works as expected.

My world definition (in CoffeeScript) looks like:

``` coffee
Mongolian = require('mongolian')

World = (callback) ->
  server = new Mongolian
  db = server.db('c100t_test')
  @db = db
  @api =
    create_user: (username, password) ->
      users = db.collection('users')
      users.insert({username, password})
  callback()

exports.World = World
```

And I try to execute it from step_definitions like:

``` coffee
wrapper = ->
  @World = require('../support/world').World
  @Given /^registered user with "([^"]*)" username and "([^"]*)" password$/, (username, password, callback) ->
    @api.create_user(username, password)
    callback()
```

mongodb logs something like:

```
Wed May  9 21:53:04 [initandlisten] connection accepted from 127.0.0.1:37289 #38
Wed May  9 21:53:04 [initandlisten] connection accepted from 127.0.0.1:37290 #39
Wed May  9 21:53:04 [conn38] end connection 127.0.0.1:37289
Wed May  9 21:53:04 [conn39] end connection 127.0.0.1:37290
```

Seems like it opens and closes connection immediately.

I tried to debug it, seems like it tries to start connection, do some work,
and then wait for some event and such event is not fired.

Maybe I don't understand something about node.js internals,
does anyone have any ideas about why might happen such a thing?

title: Handle asynchronous exceptions

milestone.title: 0.3 critical features
milestone.description: Implement those important functionalities we miss (in comparison to the Ruby big bro).

body:
Asynchronous exceptions are currently not caught: they interrupt Cucumber execution, print out the stack trace and end the process altogether.

It's possible to catch asynchronous exceptions on both Node.js and browsers through `process.on('uncaughtException', ...)` and `window.onerror`, respectively.

The catching function should call the current step `callback.fail()` function and pass it the caught exception so that Cucumber can report the failing step and proceed with the next scenario, if any.

Interesting Fact™: this will be the first piece of code in Cucumber.js that needs branching depending on wether it's running on Node or a browser.

title: Support asynchronous world constructor

milestone.title: 0.3 critical features
milestone.description: Implement those important functionalities we miss (in comparison to the Ruby big bro).

body:
I am trying to use cucumber.js to test an express.js web application.
The test scenarios are creating new objects in MongoDb database,
and I need to clear it before running the tests.

Mongodb operations are asynchronous, so if I clear the database
from world constructor, then I have a race condition with test execution.

I came up with an idea how asynchronous initialization can be supported,
please see the fork at git://github.com/salikh/cucumber-js.git.

To request asynchronous initialization, the feature writer needs
to inherit from the EventEmitter by writing the following line:

```
this.__proto__ = new process.EventEmitter
```

Then the world constructor can indicate that it finished initialization
by firing an event on itself:

```
world.emit('init done')
```

The world initializer tests if the asynchronous initialization is
required by the following condition:

```
if (world.__proto__.constructor == process.EventEmitter)
```

and if the condition matches, it starts test execution asynchronously:

```
world.on('init done', function() {
cont()
})
```

title: Unify features with cucumber-features

milestone.description: All feature elements supported by cucumber-rb must be ported to -js.

body:
cucumber-features + Aruba is now the official way of testing cucumber.js. This is great. But it would even be nicer to have cucumber.js test itself again, like in its early days. Remember: it emerged by testing itself :) 

To achieve this we need:
- JS step definitions for cucumber-features (this is easy, those already exist within cucumber_js_mappings.rb)
- create the JS mappings between those step definitions and the features ("step definitions of step definitions")
- remove redundant features from cucumber-js/features (e.g. progress_formatter.feature); we should keep the number of implementation-dependent features to a minimum, imho.
- remove old JS step definitions

Of course, running cucumber-features with cucumber.js won't generate the nice documentation we get from Aruba.

Also, the step definitions won't run the cucumber.js CLI but will directly load a Cucumber.js instance in-memory. At least for now.
